icepool

Package for computing dice and card probabilities.

See this JupyterLite distribution for examples.

Visit the project page.

General conventions:

  • Instances are immutable (apart from internal caching). Anything that looks like it mutates an instance actually returns a separate instance with the change.
  • Unless explictly specified otherwise, all sorting is in ascending order.
  • Unless explictly specified otherwise, elements with zero quantity, rolls, etc. are considered.
  • The words "min" and "max" refer to outcomes, and the words "low" and "high" refer to dice in a pool.
 1"""Package for computing dice and card probabilities.
 2
 3See [this JupyterLite distribution](https://highdiceroller.github.io/icepool/notebooks/lab/index.html)
 4for examples.
 5
 6[Visit the project page.](https://github.com/HighDiceRoller/icepool)
 7
 8General conventions:
 9
10* Instances are immutable (apart from internal caching). Anything that looks
11    like it mutates an instance actually returns a separate instance with the
12    change.
13* Unless explictly specified otherwise, all sorting is in ascending order.
14* Unless explictly specified otherwise, elements with zero quantity, rolls, etc.
15    are considered.
16* The words "min" and "max" refer to outcomes, and the words "low" and "high"
17refer to dice in a pool.
18"""

22from icepool.constant import SpecialValue

24Reroll = SpecialValue.Reroll
25"""Indicates that an outcome should be rerolled (with unlimited depth).
26
27This can be used in place of outcomes in many places. See individual function
28and method descriptions for details.
29
30This effectively removes the outcome from the probability space, along with its
31contribution to the denominator.
32
33This can be used for conditional probability by removing all outcomes not
34consistent with the given observations.
35
36Operation in specific cases:
37
38* When used with `Again`, only that stage is rerolled, not the entire `Again`
39    tree.
40* To reroll with limited depth, use `Die.reroll()`, or `Again()` with no
41    modification.
42* When used with `OutcomeCountEvaluator`, the entire evaluation is rerolled.
43"""

@cache
def standard(sides: int, /) -> icepool.Die: 
14@cache
15def standard(sides: int, /) -> 'icepool.Die':
16    """A standard die.
17
18    Specifically, the outcomes are `int`s from `1` to `sides` inclusive,
19    with quantity 1 each.
20
21    Don't confuse this with `icepool.Die()`:
22
23    * `icepool.Die([6])`: A `Die` that always rolls the integer 6.
24    * `icepool.d(6)`: A d6.
25    """
26    if not isinstance(sides, int):
27        raise TypeError('Argument to standard() must be an int.')
28    elif sides < 1:
29        raise ValueError('Standard die must have at least one side.')
30    return icepool.Die(range(1, sides + 1))

Don't confuse this with icepool.Die():

  • icepool.d(6): A d6.

def bernoulli(n: int, d: int, /) -> icepool.Die: 
52def bernoulli(n: int, d: int, /) -> 'icepool.Die':
53    """A `Die` that rolls `True` with probability `n / d`, and `False` otherwise.
54
55    If `n == 0` or `n == d` the result will have only one outcome.
56    """
57    data = {}
58    if n != d:
59        data[False] = d - n
60    if n != 0:
61        data[True] = n
62    return icepool.Die(data)

A Die that rolls True with probability n / d, and False otherwise.

If n == 0 or n == d the result will have only one outcome.

def one_hot(sides: int, /): 
68def one_hot(sides: int, /):
69    """A `Die` with tuple outcomes with one element set to `True` uniformly at random and the rest `False`.
70
71    This is an easy (if expensive) way of representing how many dice in a pool
72    rolled each number. For example, the outcomes of `10 @ one_hot(6)` are
73    the `(ones, twos, threes, fours, fives, sixes)` rolled in 10d6.
74    """
75    data = []
76    for i in range(sides):
77        outcome = [False] * sides
78        outcome[i] = True
79        data.append(tuple(outcome))
80    return icepool.Die(data)

A Die with tuple outcomes with one element set to True uniformly at random and the rest False.

This is an easy (if expensive) way of representing how many dice in a pool rolled each number. For example, the outcomes of 10 @ one_hot(6) are the (ones, twos, threes, fours, fives, sixes) rolled in 10d6.

class Die(abc.ABC, typing.Mapping[typing.Any, int]): 
  45class Die(Population):
  46    """Sampling with replacement. Quantities represent weights.
  47
  48    Dice are immutable. Methods do not modify the `Die` in-place;
  49    rather they return a `Die` representing the result.
  50
  51    It *is* (mostly) well-defined to have a `Die` with zero-quantity outcomes.
  52    These can be useful in a few cases, such as:
  53
  54    * `OutcomeCountEvaluator` will iterate through zero-quantity outcomes,
  55        rather than possibly skipping that outcome. (Though in most cases it's
  56        better to use `OutcomeCountEvaluator.alignment()`.)
  57    * `icepool.align()` and the like are convenient for making dice share the
  58        same set of outcomes.
  59
  60    However, zero-quantity outcomes have a computational cost like any other
  61    outcome. Unless you have a specific use case in mind, it's best to leave
  62    them out.
  63
  64    Most operators and methods will not introduce zero-quantity outcomes if
  65    their arguments do not have any; nor remove zero-quantity outcomes.
  66
  67    It's also possible to have "empty" dice with no outcomes at all,
  68    though these have little use other than being sentinel values.
  69    """
  70
  71    _data: Counts
  72
  73    def _new_type(self) -> type:
  74        return Die
  75
  76    def __new__(cls,
  77                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
  78                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1,
  79                *,
  80                again_depth: int = 1,
  81                again_end=None) -> 'Die':
  82        """Constructor for a `Die`.
  83
  84        Don't confuse this with `d()`:
  85
  86        * `Die([6])`: A `Die` that always rolls the `int` 6.
  87        * `d(6)`: A d6.
  88
  89        Also, don't confuse this with `Pool()`:
  90
  91        * `Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A d6.
  92        * `Pool([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A `Pool` of six dice that always rolls one
  93            of each number.
  94
  95        Here are some different ways of constructing a d6:
  96
  97        * Just import it: `from icepool import d6`
  98        * Use the `d()` function: `icepool.d(6)`
  99        * Use a d6 that you already have: `Die(d6)` or `Die([d6])`
 100        * Mix a d3 and a d3+3: `Die([d3, d3+3])`
 101        * Use a dict: `Die({1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1})`
 102        * Give the faces as a sequence: `Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`
 103
 104        All quantities must be non-negative, though they can be zero.
 105
 106        Several methods and functions foward **kwargs to this constructor.
 107        However, these only affect the construction of the returned or yielded
 108        dice. Any other implicit conversions of arguments or operands to dice
 109        will be done with the default keyword arguments.
 110
 111        EXPERIMENTAL: Use `icepool.Again()` to roll the dice again, usually with
 112        some modification. For example,
 113
 114        ```
 115        Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 + Again()])
 116        ```
 117
 118        would be an exploding d6. Use the `again_depth` parameter to control
 119        the maximum depth. `again_depth` does not apply to `Reroll`.
 120
 121        If the roll reaches the maximum depth, the `again_end` is used instead
 122        of rolling again. Options for `again_end` include:
 123
 124        * No value (`None`), which will attempt to determine a zero value from
 125            the outcomes that don't involve `Again`.
 126        * A single outcome, or a `Die`.
 127        * `Reroll`, which will reroll any end roll involving `Again`.
 128        * You could also consider some sort of placeholder value such as
 129            `math.inf`.
 130
 131        Denominator: For a flat set of outcomes, the denominator is just the
 132        sum of the corresponding quantities. If the outcomes themselves have
 133        secondary denominators, then the overall denominator is the primary
 134        denominator times the LCM of the outcome denominators.
 135
 136        For example, `Die([d3, d4, d6])` has a final denominator of 36: 3 for
 137        the primary selection between the three secondary dice, times 12 for
 138        the LCM of 3, 4, and 6.
 139
 140        Args:
 141            outcomes: The faces of the `Die`. This can be one of the following:
 142                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
 143                * A sequence of outcomes. Each element will have the same total
 144                    quantity.
 145
 146                Note that `Die` and `Deck` both count as `Mapping`s.
 147                Each outcome may be one of the following:
 148                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
 149                    The outcomes of the `Mapping` will be "flattened" into the
 150                    result. This option will be taken in preference to treating
 151                    the `Mapping` itself as an outcome even if the `Mapping`
 152                    itself is hashable and totally orderable. This means that
 153                    `Die` and `Deck` will never be outcomes.
 154                * A tuple of outcomes. Operators on dice with tuple outcomes
 155                    are performed element-wise. See `Die.unary_op` and
 156                    `Die.binary_op` for details.
 157
 158                    Any tuple elements that are `Mapping`s will expand the
 159                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
 160                    For example, `(d6, d6)` will expand to 36 ordered tuples
 161                    with quantity 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a
 162                    large number of outcomes.
 163                * `str` or `bytes`, which will be treated as a single outcome.
 164                * Any other sequence. Each element will be weighted equally.
 165                * `icepool.Reroll`, which will drop itself
 166                    and the corresponding element of `times` from consideration.
 167                    If inside a tuple, the tuple will be dropped.
 168                * Anything else will be treated as a single outcome.
 169                    Each outcome must be hashable, and the
 170                    set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion).
 171                    The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case
 172                    the corresponding quantities will be accumulated.
 173            times: Multiplies the quantity of each element of `outcomes`.
 174                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 175                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 176                `outcomes`.
 177        Raises:
 178            ValueError: `None` is not a valid outcome for a `Die`.
 179        """
 180        if isinstance(outcomes, Die):
 181            if times == 1:
 182                return outcomes
 183            else:
 184                outcomes = outcomes._data
 185        else:
 186            # Check for Again.
 187            if icepool.again.contains_again(outcomes):
 188                if again_end is None:
 189                    # Create a test die with `Again`s removed,
 190                    # then find the zero.
 191                    test = Die(outcomes,
 192                               again_depth=0,
 193                               again_end=icepool.Reroll)
 194                    if len(test) == 0:
 195                        raise ValueError(
 196                            'If all outcomes contain Again, an explicit again_end must be provided.'
 197                        )
 198                    again_end = test.zero().simplify()
 199                else:
 200                    again_end = implicit_convert_to_die(again_end)
 201                    if icepool.again.contains_again(again_end):
 202                        raise ValueError(
 203                            'again_end cannot itself contain Again.')
 204                if again_depth == 0:
 205                    # Base case.
 206                    outcomes = icepool.again.sub_agains(outcomes, again_end)
 207                else:
 208                    tail = Die(outcomes,
 209                               times,
 210                               again_depth=again_depth - 1,
 211                               again_end=again_end)
 212                    outcomes = icepool.again.sub_agains(outcomes, tail)
 213
 214        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
 215
 216        if len(outcomes) == 1 and times[0] == 1 and isinstance(
 217                outcomes[0], Die):
 218            return outcomes[0]
 219
 220        self = super(Population, cls).__new__(cls)
 221        self._data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_die(outcomes, times)
 222        return self
 223
 224    def unary_op(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
 225        """Performs the unary operation on the outcomes.
 226
 227        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
 228        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
 229        rather than an operator.
 230
 231        This is used for the standard unary operators
 232        `-, +, abs, ~, round, trunc, floor, ceil`
 233        as well as the additional methods
 234        `zero, bool`.
 235
 236        This is NOT used for the `[]` operator; when used directly, this is
 237        interpreted as a `Mapping` operation and returns the count corresponding
 238        to a given outcome. See `marginals()` for applying the `[]` operator to
 239        outcomes.
 240
 241        Returns:
 242            A `Die` representing the result.
 243
 244        Raises:
 245            ValueError: If tuples are of mismatched length.
 246        """
 247        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 248        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
 249            new_outcome = unary_elementwise(outcome, op, *args, **kwargs)
 250            data[new_outcome] += quantity
 251        return icepool.Die(data)
 252
 253    def binary_op(self, other: 'Die', op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
 254        """Performs the operation on pairs of outcomes.
 255
 256        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
 257        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
 258        rather than an operator.
 259
 260        By the time this is called, the other operand has already been
 261        converted to a `Die`.
 262
 263        This is used for the standard binary operators
 264        `+, -, *, /, //, %, **, <<, >>, &, |, ^`.
 265        Note that `*` multiplies outcomes directly;
 266        it is not the same as `@`, which rolls the right side multiple times,
 267        or `d()`, which creates a standard die.
 268
 269        The comparators (`<, <=, >=, >, ==, !=, cmp`) use a linear algorithm
 270        using the fact that outcomes are totally ordered.
 271
 272        `==` and `!=` additionally set the truth value of the `Die` according to
 273        whether the dice themselves are the same or not.
 274
 275        The `@` operator does NOT use this method directly.
 276        It rolls the left `Die`, which must have integer outcomes,
 277        then rolls the right `Die` that many times and sums the outcomes.
 278        Only the sum is performed element-wise.
 279
 280        Returns:
 281            A `Die` representing the result.
 282
 283        Raises:
 284            ValueError: If tuples are of mismatched length within one of the
 285                dice or between the dice.
 286        """
 287        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 288        for (outcome_self,
 289             quantity_self), (outcome_other,
 290                              quantity_other) in itertools.product(
 291                                  self.items(), other.items()):
 292            new_outcome = binary_elementwise(outcome_self, outcome_other, op,
 293                                             *args, **kwargs)
 294            data[new_outcome] += quantity_self * quantity_other
 295        return icepool.Die(data)
 296
 297    # Basic access.
 298
 299    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView:
 300        return self._data.keys()
 301
 302    def values(self) -> CountsValuesView:
 303        return self._data.values()
 304
 305    def items(self) -> CountsItemsView:
 306        return self._data.items()
 307
 308    def __getitem__(self, outcome, /) -> int:
 309        return self._data[outcome]
 310
 311    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator:
 312        return iter(self.keys())
 313
 314    def __len__(self) -> int:
 315        """The number of outcomes. """
 316        return len(self._data)
 317
 318    def __contains__(self, outcome) -> bool:
 319        return outcome in self._data
 320
 321    # Quantity management.
 322
 323    def simplify(self) -> 'Die':
 324        """Divides all quantities by their greatest common denominator. """
 325        return icepool.Die(self._data.simplify())
 326
 327    # Rerolls and other outcome management.
 328
 329    def reroll(self,
 330               outcomes: Callable[..., bool] | Container | None = None,
 331               *extra_args,
 332               depth: int | None = None,
 333               star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 334        """Rerolls the given outcomes.
 335
 336        Args:
 337            outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll. Options:
 338                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
 339                    should be rerolled.
 340                * A container of outcomes to reroll.
 341                * If not provided, the min outcome will be rerolled.
 342            *extra_args: These will be supplied to `outcomes` as extra
 343                positional arguments after the outcome argument(s).
 344                `extra_args` can only be supplied if `outcomes` is callable.
 345            depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
 346                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
 347            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
 348                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
 349                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
 350
 351        Returns:
 352            A `Die` representing the reroll.
 353            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
 354
 355        Raises:
 356            ValueError: If `extra_args` are supplied with a non-callable `outcomes`.
 357        """
 358        if extra_args and not callable(outcomes):
 359            raise ValueError(
 360                'Extra positional arguments are only valid if outcomes is callable.'
 361            )
 362
 363        if outcomes is None:
 364            outcomes = {self.min_outcome()}
 365        elif callable(outcomes):
 366            if star:
 367                outcomes = {
 368                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 369                    if outcomes(*outcome, *extra_args)
 370                }
 371            else:
 372                outcomes = {
 373                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 374                    if outcomes(outcome, *extra_args)
 375                }
 376
 377        if depth is None:
 378            data = {
 379                outcome: quantity
 380                for outcome, quantity in self.items()
 381                if outcome not in outcomes
 382            }
 383        else:
 384            total_reroll_quantity = sum(
 385                quantity for outcome, quantity in self.items()
 386                if outcome in outcomes)
 387            rerollable_factor = total_reroll_quantity**depth
 388            stop_factor = (self.denominator()**depth +
 389                           total_reroll_quantity**depth)
 390            data = {
 391                outcome:
 392                (rerollable_factor *
 393                 quantity if outcome in outcomes else stop_factor * quantity)
 394                for outcome, quantity in self.items()
 395            }
 396        return icepool.Die(data)
 397
 398    def reroll_until(self,
 399                     outcomes: Callable[..., bool] | Container,
 400                     *extra_args,
 401                     depth: int | None = None,
 402                     star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 403        """Rerolls until getting one of the given outcomes.
 404
 405        Essentially the complement of `reroll()`.
 406
 407        Args:
 408            outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll until. Options:
 409                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
 410                    should be accepted.
 411                * A container of outcomes to reroll until.
 412            *extra_args: These will be supplied to `outcomes` as extra
 413                positional arguments after the outcome argument(s).
 414                `extra_args` can only be supplied if `outcomes` is callable.
 415            depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
 416                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
 417            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
 418                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
 419                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
 420
 421        Returns:
 422            A `Die` representing the reroll.
 423            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
 424
 425        Raises:
 426            ValueError: If `extra_args` are supplied with a non-callable `outcomes`.
 427        """
 428        if extra_args and not callable(outcomes):
 429            raise ValueError(
 430                'Extra positional arguments are only valid if outcomes is callable.'
 431            )
 432
 433        if callable(outcomes):
 434            if star:
 435                not_outcomes = {
 436                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 437                    if not outcomes(*outcome, *extra_args)
 438                }
 439            else:
 440                not_outcomes = {
 441                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 442                    if not outcomes(outcome, *extra_args)
 443                }
 444        else:
 445            not_outcomes = {
 446                not_outcome for not_outcome in self.outcomes()
 447                if not_outcome not in outcomes
 448            }
 449        return self.reroll(not_outcomes, depth=depth)
 450
 451    def truncate(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
 452        """Truncates the outcomes of this `Die` to the given range.
 453
 454        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
 455        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.
 456
 457        This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range.
 458        If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint,
 459        use `clip()`.
 460
 461        Not to be confused with `trunc(die)`, which performs integer truncation
 462        on each outcome.
 463        """
 464        if min_outcome is not None:
 465            start = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), min_outcome)
 466        else:
 467            start = None
 468        if max_outcome is not None:
 469            stop = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), max_outcome)
 470        else:
 471            stop = None
 472        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items()[start:stop]}
 473        return icepool.Die(data)
 474
 475    def clip(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
 476        """Clips the outcomes of this `Die` to the given values.
 477
 478        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
 479        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be clipped.
 480
 481        This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range;
 482        the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range.
 483        This will typically cause some quantity to bunch up at the endpoint.
 484        If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use `truncate()`.
 485        """
 486        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 487        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
 488            if min_outcome is not None and outcome <= min_outcome:
 489                data[min_outcome] += quantity
 490            elif max_outcome is not None and outcome >= max_outcome:
 491                data[max_outcome] += quantity
 492            else:
 493                data[outcome] += quantity
 494        return icepool.Die(data)
 495
 496    def set_range(self,
 497                  min_outcome: int | None = None,
 498                  max_outcome: int | None = None) -> 'Die':
 499        """Sets the outcomes of this `Die` to the given `int` range (inclusive).
 500
 501        Args:
 502            min_outcome: The min outcome of the result.
 503                If omitted, the min outcome of this `Die` will be used.
 504            max_outcome: The max outcome of the result.
 505                If omitted, the max outcome of this `Die` will be used.
 506        """
 507        if min_outcome is None:
 508            min_outcome = self.min_outcome()
 509        if max_outcome is None:
 510            max_outcome = self.max_outcome()
 511
 512        return self.set_outcomes(range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1))
 513
 514    def set_outcomes(self, outcomes) -> 'Die':
 515        """Sets the set of outcomes to the argument.
 516
 517        This may remove outcomes (if they are not present in the argument)
 518        and/or add zero-quantity outcomes (if they are not present in this `Die`).
 519        """
 520        data = {x: self.quantity(x) for x in outcomes}
 521        return icepool.Die(data)
 522
 523    def trim(self) -> 'Die':
 524        """Removes all zero-quantity outcomes. """
 525        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items() if v > 0}
 526        return icepool.Die(data)
 527
 528    @cached_property
 529    def _popped_min(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 530        die = icepool.Die(self._data.remove_min())
 531        return die, self.quantities()[0]
 532
 533    def _pop_min(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 534        """A `Die` with the min outcome removed, and the quantity of the removed outcome.
 535
 536        Raises:
 537            IndexError: If this `Die` has no outcome to pop.
 538        """
 539        return self._popped_min
 540
 541    @cached_property
 542    def _popped_max(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 543        die = icepool.Die(self._data.remove_max())
 544        return die, self.quantities()[-1]
 545
 546    def _pop_max(self) -> tuple['Die', int]:
 547        """A `Die` with the max outcome removed, and the quantity of the removed outcome.
 548
 549        Raises:
 550            IndexError: If this `Die` has no outcome to pop.
 551        """
 552        return self._popped_max
 553
 554    # Mixtures.
 555
 556    def sub(self,
 557            repl: Callable | Mapping,
 558            /,
 559            repeat: int | None = 1,
 560            star: int = 0,
 561            again_depth: int = 1,
 562            again_end=None) -> 'Die':
 563        """Changes outcomes of the `Die` to other outcomes.
 564
 565        You can think of this as `sub`stituting outcomes of this `Die` for other
 566        outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a `sub`routine based on the roll of
 567        this `Die`.
 568
 569        EXPERIMENTAL: `Again`, `again_depth`, and `again_end` can be used as the
 570        `Die()` constructor. It is not advised to use these with `repeat` other
 571        than 1.
 572
 573        Args:
 574            repl: One of the following:
 575                * A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
 576                * A map from old outcomes to new outcomes.
 577                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
 578                The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes.
 579                The special value `icepool.Reroll` will reroll that old outcome.
 580            repeat: `sub()` will be repeated with the same argument on the
 581                result this many times.
 582
 583                EXPERIMENTAL: If set to `None`, the result will be as if `sub()`
 584                    were repeated an infinite number of times. In this case, the
 585                    result will be in simplest form.
 586            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes of `self` will be unpacked as
 587                `*outcome` before giving it to the `repl` function. `extra_dice`
 588                are not unpacked. If `repl` is not a callable, this has no
 589                effect.
 590            again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
 591            again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
 592
 593        Returns:
 594            The `Die` after the modification.
 595        """
 596
 597        if repeat == 0:
 598            return self
 599
 600        # Convert to a single-argument function.
 601        if callable(repl):
 602            if star:
 603
 604                def transition_function(outcome):
 605                    return repl(*outcome)
 606            else:
 607
 608                def transition_function(outcome):
 609                    return repl(outcome)
 610        else:
 611            # repl is a mapping.
 612            def transition_function(outcome):
 613                if outcome in repl:
 614                    return repl[outcome]
 615                else:
 616                    return outcome
 617
 618        if repeat is not None:
 619            result = self
 620            for _ in range(repeat):
 621                result = icepool.apply(transition_function,
 622                                       result,
 623                                       again_depth=again_depth,
 624                                       again_end=again_end)
 625            return result
 626        else:
 627            # Infinite repeat.
 628            return icepool.markov_chain.absorbing_markov_chain(
 629                self, transition_function)
 630
 631    def explode(self,
 632                outcomes: Container | Callable[..., bool] | None = None,
 633                *extra_args,
 634                depth: int = 9,
 635                end=None,
 636                star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 637        """Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.
 638
 639        Args:
 640            outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
 641                * An container of outcomes to explode.
 642                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
 643                    should be exploded.
 644                * If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
 645            *extra_args: These will be supplied to `outcomes` as extra
 646                positional arguments after the outcome argument(s).
 647                `extra_args` can only be supplied if `outcomes` is callable.
 648            depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll.
 649                If not supplied, a default value will be used.
 650            end: Once depth is reached, further explosions will be treated
 651                as this value. By default, a zero value will be used.
 652            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
 653                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
 654                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
 655
 656        Raises:
 657            ValueError: If `extra_args` are supplied with a non-callable `outcomes`.
 658        """
 659        if extra_args and not callable(outcomes):
 660            raise ValueError(
 661                'Extra positional arguments are only valid if outcomes is callable.'
 662            )
 663
 664        if outcomes is None:
 665            outcomes = {self.max_outcome()}
 666        elif callable(outcomes):
 667            if star:
 668                outcomes = {
 669                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 670                    if outcomes(*outcome, *extra_args)
 671                }
 672            else:
 673                outcomes = {
 674                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
 675                    if outcomes(outcome, *extra_args)
 676                }
 677        else:
 678            if not outcomes:
 679                return self
 680
 681        if depth < 0:
 682            raise ValueError('depth cannot be negative.')
 683        elif depth == 0:
 684            return self
 685
 686        def sub_func(outcome):
 687            if outcome in outcomes:
 688                return outcome + icepool.Again()
 689            else:
 690                return outcome
 691
 692        return self.sub(sub_func, again_depth=depth, again_end=end)
 693
 694    def if_else(self,
 695                outcome_if_true,
 696                outcome_if_false,
 697                /,
 698                again_depth: int = 1,
 699                again_end=None) -> 'Die':
 700        """Ternary conditional operator.
 701
 702        This replaces truthy outcomes with the first argument and falsy outcomes
 703        with the second argument.
 704
 705        Args:
 706            again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
 707            again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
 708        """
 709        return self.bool().sub(lambda x: outcome_if_true
 710                               if x else outcome_if_false,
 711                               again_depth=again_depth,
 712                               again_end=again_end)
 713
 714    def is_in(self, target: Container, /) -> 'Die':
 715        """A die that returns True iff the roll of the die is contained in the target."""
 716        return self.sub(lambda x: x in target)
 717
 718    def count(self, rolls: int, target, /) -> 'Die':
 719        """Roll this dice a number of time and count how many are == the target."""
 720        return rolls @ (self == target)
 721
 722    def count_in(self, rolls: int, target: Container, /) -> 'Die':
 723        """Roll this dice a number of time and count how many are in the target."""
 724        return rolls @ self.is_in(target)
 725
 726    # Pools and sums.
 727
 728    @cached_property
 729    def _sum_cache(self) -> MutableMapping[int, 'Die']:
 730        return {}
 731
 732    def _sum_all(self, rolls: int, /) -> 'Die':
 733        """Roll this `Die` `rolls` times and sum the results.
 734
 735        If `rolls` is negative, roll the `Die` `abs(rolls)` times and negate
 736        the result.
 737
 738        If you instead want to replace tuple (or other sequence) outcomes with
 739        their sum, use `die.sub(sum)`.
 740        """
 741        if rolls in self._sum_cache:
 742            return self._sum_cache[rolls]
 743
 744        if rolls < 0:
 745            result = -self._sum_all(-rolls)
 746        elif rolls == 0:
 747            result = self.zero()
 748        elif rolls == 1:
 749            result = self
 750        else:
 751            # Binary split seems to perform much worse.
 752            result = self + self._sum_all(rolls - 1)
 753
 754        self._sum_cache[rolls] = result
 755        return result
 756
 757    def __matmul__(self, other) -> 'Die':
 758        """Roll the left `Die`, then roll the right `Die` that many times and sum the outcomes."""
 759        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
 760            return NotImplemented
 761        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
 762
 763        data: MutableMapping[int, Any] = defaultdict(int)
 764
 765        max_abs_die_count = max(abs(self.min_outcome()),
 766                                abs(self.max_outcome()))
 767        for die_count, die_count_quantity in self.items():
 768            factor = other.denominator()**(max_abs_die_count - abs(die_count))
 769            subresult = other._sum_all(die_count)
 770            for outcome, subresult_quantity in subresult.items():
 771                data[
 772                    outcome] += subresult_quantity * die_count_quantity * factor
 773
 774        return icepool.Die(data)
 775
 776    def __rmatmul__(self, other) -> 'Die':
 777        """Roll the left `Die`, then roll the right `Die` that many times and sum the outcomes."""
 778        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
 779            return NotImplemented
 780        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
 781        return other.__matmul__(self)
 782
 783    def pool(self, rolls: int | Sequence[int], /) -> 'icepool.Pool':
 784        """Creates a `Pool` from this `Die`.
 785
 786        You might subscript the pool immediately afterwards, e.g.
 787        `d6.pool(5)[-1, ..., 1]` takes the difference between the highest and
 788        lowest of 5d6.
 789
 790        Args:
 791            rolls: The number of copies of this `Die` to put in the pool.
 792                Or, a sequence of one `int` per die acting as
 793                `sorted_roll_counts`. Note that `...` cannot be used in the
 794                argument to this method, as the argument determines the size of
 795                the pool.
 796        """
 797        if isinstance(rolls, int):
 798            return icepool.Pool({self: rolls})
 799        else:
 800            pool_size = len(rolls)
 801            return icepool.Pool({self: pool_size})[rolls]
 802
 803    def keep_lowest(self, rolls: int, /, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 804        """Roll several of this `Die` and sum the sorted results from the lowest.
 805
 806        Args:
 807            rolls: The number of dice to roll. All dice will have the same
 808                outcomes as `self`.
 809            keep: The number of dice to keep.
 810            drop: If provided, this many lowest dice will be dropped before
 811                keeping.
 812
 813        Returns:
 814            A `Die` representing the probability distribution of the sum.
 815        """
 816        if keep == 1 and drop == 0:
 817            return self._keep_lowest_single(rolls)
 818
 819        start = drop if drop > 0 else None
 820        stop = keep + (drop or 0)
 821        sorted_roll_counts = slice(start, stop)
 822        return self.pool(rolls)[sorted_roll_counts].sum()
 823
 824    def _keep_lowest_single(self, rolls: int, /) -> 'Die':
 825        """Faster algorithm for keeping just the single lowest `Die`. """
 826        if rolls == 0:
 827            return self.zero()
 828        return icepool.from_cumulative_quantities(
 829            self.outcomes(), [x**rolls for x in self.quantities_ge()],
 830            reverse=True)
 831
 832    def keep_highest(self,
 833                     rolls: int,
 834                     /,
 835                     keep: int = 1,
 836                     drop: int = 0) -> 'Die':
 837        """Roll several of this `Die` and sum the sorted results from the highest.
 838
 839        Args:
 840            rolls: The number of dice to roll.
 841            keep: The number of dice to keep.
 842            drop: If provided, this many highest dice will be dropped before
 843                keeping.
 844
 845        Returns:
 846            A `Die` representing the probability distribution of the sum.
 847        """
 848        if keep == 1 and drop == 0:
 849            return self._keep_highest_single(rolls)
 850        start = -(keep + (drop or 0))
 851        stop = -drop if drop > 0 else None
 852        sorted_roll_counts = slice(start, stop)
 853        return self.pool(rolls)[sorted_roll_counts].sum()
 854
 855    def _keep_highest_single(self, rolls: int, /) -> 'Die':
 856        """Faster algorithm for keeping just the single highest `Die`. """
 857        if rolls == 0:
 858            return self.zero()
 859        return icepool.from_cumulative_quantities(
 860            self.outcomes(), [x**rolls for x in self.quantities_le()])
 861

 879        return self.unary_op(round, ndigits)

 884        return self.unary_op(math.trunc)

 898    @staticmethod
 899    def _zero(x):
 900        return type(x)()
 901
 902    def zero(self) -> 'Die':
 903        """Zeros all outcomes of this die.
 904
 905        This is done by calling the constructor for each outcome's type with no
 906        arguments.
 907
 908        The result will have the same denominator as this die.
 909
 910        Raises:
 911            ValueError: If the zeros did not resolve to a single outcome.
 912        """
 913        result = self.unary_op(Die._zero)
 914        if len(result) != 1:
 915            raise ValueError('zero() did not resolve to a single outcome.')
 916        return result
 917
 918    def zero_outcome(self):
 919        """A zero-outcome for this die.
 920
 921        E.g. `0` for a `Die` whose outcomes are `int`s.
 922        """
 923        return self.zero().outcomes()[0]

1035    def __and__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1036        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
1037            return NotImplemented
1038        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1039        return self.binary_op(other, operator.and_)
1040
1041    def __rand__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1042        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
1043            return NotImplemented
1044        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1045        return other.binary_op(self, operator.and_)
1046
1047    def __or__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1048        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
1049            return NotImplemented
1050        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1051        return self.binary_op(other, operator.or_)
1052
1053    def __ror__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1054        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
1055            return NotImplemented
1056        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1057        return other.binary_op(self, operator.or_)
1058
1059    def __xor__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1060        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
1061            return NotImplemented
1062        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1063        return self.binary_op(other, operator.xor)
1064
1065    def __rxor__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1066        if isinstance(other, icepool.Again):
1067            return NotImplemented
1068        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1069        return other.binary_op(self, operator.xor)
1070
1071    # Comparators.
1072
1073    @staticmethod
1074    def _lt_le(op: Callable, lo: 'Die', hi: 'Die') -> 'Die':
1075        """Linear algorithm for < and <=.
1076
1077        Args:
1078            op: Either `operator.lt` or `operator.le`.
1079            lo: The `Die` on the left of `op`.
1080            hi: The `Die` on the right of `op`.
1081        """
1082        if lo.is_empty() or hi.is_empty():
1083            return icepool.Die([])
1084
1085        d = lo.denominator() * hi.denominator()
1086
1087        # One-outcome cases.
1088
1089        if op(lo.max_outcome(), hi.min_outcome()):
1090            return icepool.Die({True: d})
1091
1092        if not op(lo.min_outcome(), hi.max_outcome()):
1093            return icepool.Die({False: d})
1094
1095        n = 0
1096
1097        lo_cweight = 0
1098        lo_iter = iter(zip(lo.outcomes(), lo.quantities_le()))
1099        lo_outcome, next_lo_cweight = next(lo_iter)
1100        for hi_outcome, hi_weight in hi.items():
1101            while op(lo_outcome, hi_outcome):
1102                try:
1103                    lo_cweight = next_lo_cweight
1104                    lo_outcome, next_lo_cweight = next(lo_iter)
1105                except StopIteration:
1106                    break
1107            n += lo_cweight * hi_weight
1108
1109        # We don't use bernoulli because it trims zero-quantity outcomes.
1110        return icepool.Die({False: d - n, True: n})
1111
1112    def __lt__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1113        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1114        return Die._lt_le(operator.lt, self, other)
1115
1116    def __le__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1117        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1118        return Die._lt_le(operator.le, self, other)
1119
1120    def __ge__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1121        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1122        return Die._lt_le(operator.le, other, self)
1123
1124    def __gt__(self, other) -> 'Die':
1125        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1126        return Die._lt_le(operator.lt, other, self)
1127
1128    # Equality operators. These produce a `DieWithTruth`.
1129
1130    @staticmethod
1131    def _eq(invert: bool, a: 'Die', b: 'Die') -> 'Counts':
1132        """Linear algorithm for == and !=.
1133
1134        Args:
1135            invert: If `False`, this computes ==; if `True` this computes !=.
1136            a, b: The dice.
1137        """
1138        if a.is_empty() or b.is_empty():
1139            return Counts([])
1140
1141        d = a.denominator() * b.denominator()
1142
1143        # Single-outcome case.
1144        if (a.keys().isdisjoint(b.keys())):
1145            return Counts([(invert, d)])
1146
1147        n = 0
1148
1149        a_iter = iter(a.items())
1150        b_iter = iter(b.items())
1151
1152        a_outcome, a_quantity = next(a_iter)
1153        b_outcome, b_quantity = next(b_iter)
1154
1155        while True:
1156            try:
1157                if a_outcome == b_outcome:
1158                    n += a_quantity * b_quantity
1159                    a_outcome, a_quantity = next(a_iter)
1160                    b_outcome, b_quantity = next(b_iter)
1161                elif a_outcome < b_outcome:
1162                    a_outcome, a_quantity = next(a_iter)
1163                else:
1164                    b_outcome, b_quantity = next(b_iter)
1165            except StopIteration:
1166                if invert:
1167                    return Counts([(False, n), (True, d - n)])
1168                else:
1169                    return Counts([(False, d - n), (True, n)])
1170
1171    def __eq__(self, other):
1172        other_die = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1173
1174        def data_callback():
1175            return Die._eq(False, self, other_die)
1176
1177        def truth_value_callback():
1178            return self.equals(other)
1179
1180        return icepool.DieWithTruth(data_callback, truth_value_callback)
1181
1182    def __ne__(self, other):
1183        other_die = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1184
1185        def data_callback():
1186            return Die._eq(True, self, other_die)
1187
1188        def truth_value_callback():
1189            return not self.equals(other)
1190
1191        return icepool.DieWithTruth(data_callback, truth_value_callback)
1192
1193    def cmp(self, other) -> 'Die':
1194        """A `Die` with outcomes 1, -1, and 0.
1195
1196        The quantities are equal to the positive outcome of `self > other`,
1197        `self < other`, and the remainder respectively.
1198
1199        This will include all three outcomes even if they have zero quantity.
1200        """
1201        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1202
1203        data = {}
1204
1205        lt = self < other
1206        if True in lt:
1207            data[-1] = lt[True]
1208        eq = self == other
1209        if True in eq:
1210            data[0] = eq[True]
1211        gt = self > other
1212        if True in gt:
1213            data[1] = gt[True]
1214
1215        return Die(data)
1216
1217    @staticmethod
1218    def _sign(x) -> int:
1219        z = Die._zero(x)
1220        if x > z:
1221            return 1
1222        elif x < z:
1223            return -1
1224        else:
1225            return 0
1226
1227    def sign(self) -> 'Die':
1228        """Outcomes become 1 if greater than `zero()`, -1 if less than `zero()`, and 0 otherwise.
1229
1230        Note that for `float`s, +0.0, -0.0, and nan all become 0.
1231        """
1232        return self.unary_op(Die._sign)
1233
1234    def bool(self) -> 'Die':
1235        """Takes `bool()` of all outcomes.
1236
1237        Note that a `Die` as a whole is not considered to have a truth value
1238        unless it is the result of the `==` or `!=` operators.
1239        """
1240        return self.unary_op(bool)
1241
1242    # Equality and hashing.
1243
1244    def __bool__(self):
1245        raise ValueError(
1246            'A `Die` only has a truth value if it is the result of == or !=. '
1247            'If this is in the conditional of an if-statement, you probably '
1248            'want to use die.if_else() instead.')
1249
1250    @cached_property
1251    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
1252        return tuple(self.items())
1253
1254    def key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
1255        """A tuple that uniquely (as `equals()`) identifies this die.
1256
1257        Apart from being hashable and totally orderable, this is not guaranteed
1258        to be in any particular format or have any other properties.
1259        """
1260        return self._key_tuple
1261
1262    @cached_property
1263    def _hash(self) -> int:
1264        return hash(self.key_tuple())
1265
1266    def __hash__(self) -> int:
1267        return self._hash
1268
1269    def equals(self, other, *, simplify=False):
1270        """`True` iff both dice have the same outcomes and quantities.
1271
1272        This is `False` if `other` is not a `Die`, even if it would convert
1273        to an equal `Die`.
1274
1275        Truth value does NOT matter.
1276
1277        If one `Die` has a zero-quantity outcome and the other `Die` does not
1278        contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.
1279
1280        The `==` and `!=` operators have a dual purpose; they return a `Die`
1281        with a truth value determined by this method.
1282        Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of
1283        these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested
1284        in the `Die` value or the truth value.
1285
1286        Args:
1287            simplify: If `True`, the dice will be simplified before comparing.
1288                Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not `equals()` to a 1:1 coin.
1289        """
1290        if not isinstance(other, Die):
1291            return False
1292
1293        if simplify:
1294            return self.simplify().key_tuple() == other.simplify().key_tuple()
1295        else:
1296            return self.key_tuple() == other.key_tuple()
1297
1298    # Strings.
1299
1300    def __repr__(self) -> str:
1301        inner = ', '.join(
1302            f'{outcome}: {weight}' for outcome, weight in self.items())
1303        return type(self).__qualname__ + '({' + inner + '})'

Sampling with replacement. Quantities represent weights.

Dice are immutable. Methods do not modify the Die in-place; rather they return a Die representing the result.

It is (mostly) well-defined to have a Die with zero-quantity outcomes. These can be useful in a few cases, such as:

  • OutcomeCountEvaluator will iterate through zero-quantity outcomes, rather than possibly skipping that outcome. (Though in most cases it's better to use OutcomeCountEvaluator.alignment().)
  • icepool.align() and the like are convenient for making dice share the same set of outcomes.

However, zero-quantity outcomes have a computational cost like any other outcome. Unless you have a specific use case in mind, it's best to leave them out.

Most operators and methods will not introduce zero-quantity outcomes if their arguments do not have any; nor remove zero-quantity outcomes.

It's also possible to have "empty" dice with no outcomes at all, though these have little use other than being sentinel values.

Die( outcomes: Union[Mapping[Any, int], Sequence], times: Union[Sequence[int], int] = 1, *, again_depth: int = 1, again_end=None) 
 76    def __new__(cls,
 77                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 78                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1,
 79                *,
 80                again_depth: int = 1,
 81                again_end=None) -> 'Die':
 82        """Constructor for a `Die`.
 83
 84        Don't confuse this with `d()`:
 85
 86        * `Die([6])`: A `Die` that always rolls the `int` 6.
 87        * `d(6)`: A d6.
 88
 89        Also, don't confuse this with `Pool()`:
 90
 91        * `Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A d6.
 92        * `Pool([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`: A `Pool` of six dice that always rolls one
 93            of each number.
 94
 95        Here are some different ways of constructing a d6:
 96
 97        * Just import it: `from icepool import d6`
 98        * Use the `d()` function: `icepool.d(6)`
 99        * Use a d6 that you already have: `Die(d6)` or `Die([d6])`
100        * Mix a d3 and a d3+3: `Die([d3, d3+3])`
101        * Use a dict: `Die({1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1})`
102        * Give the faces as a sequence: `Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])`
103
104        All quantities must be non-negative, though they can be zero.
105
106        Several methods and functions foward **kwargs to this constructor.
107        However, these only affect the construction of the returned or yielded
108        dice. Any other implicit conversions of arguments or operands to dice
109        will be done with the default keyword arguments.
110
111        EXPERIMENTAL: Use `icepool.Again()` to roll the dice again, usually with
112        some modification. For example,
113
114        ```
115        Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 + Again()])
116        ```
117
118        would be an exploding d6. Use the `again_depth` parameter to control
119        the maximum depth. `again_depth` does not apply to `Reroll`.
120
121        If the roll reaches the maximum depth, the `again_end` is used instead
122        of rolling again. Options for `again_end` include:
123
124        * No value (`None`), which will attempt to determine a zero value from
125            the outcomes that don't involve `Again`.
126        * A single outcome, or a `Die`.
127        * `Reroll`, which will reroll any end roll involving `Again`.
128        * You could also consider some sort of placeholder value such as
129            `math.inf`.
130
131        Denominator: For a flat set of outcomes, the denominator is just the
132        sum of the corresponding quantities. If the outcomes themselves have
133        secondary denominators, then the overall denominator is the primary
134        denominator times the LCM of the outcome denominators.
135
136        For example, `Die([d3, d4, d6])` has a final denominator of 36: 3 for
137        the primary selection between the three secondary dice, times 12 for
138        the LCM of 3, 4, and 6.
139
140        Args:
141            outcomes: The faces of the `Die`. This can be one of the following:
142                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
143                * A sequence of outcomes. Each element will have the same total
144                    quantity.
145
146                Note that `Die` and `Deck` both count as `Mapping`s.
147                Each outcome may be one of the following:
148                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
149                    The outcomes of the `Mapping` will be "flattened" into the
150                    result. This option will be taken in preference to treating
151                    the `Mapping` itself as an outcome even if the `Mapping`
152                    itself is hashable and totally orderable. This means that
153                    `Die` and `Deck` will never be outcomes.
154                * A tuple of outcomes. Operators on dice with tuple outcomes
155                    are performed element-wise. See `Die.unary_op` and
156                    `Die.binary_op` for details.
157
158                    Any tuple elements that are `Mapping`s will expand the
159                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
160                    For example, `(d6, d6)` will expand to 36 ordered tuples
161                    with quantity 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a
162                    large number of outcomes.
163                * `str` or `bytes`, which will be treated as a single outcome.
164                * Any other sequence. Each element will be weighted equally.
165                * `icepool.Reroll`, which will drop itself
166                    and the corresponding element of `times` from consideration.
167                    If inside a tuple, the tuple will be dropped.
168                * Anything else will be treated as a single outcome.
169                    Each outcome must be hashable, and the
170                    set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion).
171                    The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case
172                    the corresponding quantities will be accumulated.
173            times: Multiplies the quantity of each element of `outcomes`.
174                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
175                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
176                `outcomes`.
177        Raises:
178            ValueError: `None` is not a valid outcome for a `Die`.
179        """
180        if isinstance(outcomes, Die):
181            if times == 1:
182                return outcomes
183            else:
184                outcomes = outcomes._data
185        else:
186            # Check for Again.
187            if icepool.again.contains_again(outcomes):
188                if again_end is None:
189                    # Create a test die with `Again`s removed,
190                    # then find the zero.
191                    test = Die(outcomes,
192                               again_depth=0,
193                               again_end=icepool.Reroll)
194                    if len(test) == 0:
195                        raise ValueError(
196                            'If all outcomes contain Again, an explicit again_end must be provided.'
197                        )
198                    again_end = test.zero().simplify()
199                else:
200                    again_end = implicit_convert_to_die(again_end)
201                    if icepool.again.contains_again(again_end):
202                        raise ValueError(
203                            'again_end cannot itself contain Again.')
204                if again_depth == 0:
205                    # Base case.
206                    outcomes = icepool.again.sub_agains(outcomes, again_end)
207                else:
208                    tail = Die(outcomes,
209                               times,
210                               again_depth=again_depth - 1,
211                               again_end=again_end)
212                    outcomes = icepool.again.sub_agains(outcomes, tail)
213
214        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
215
216        if len(outcomes) == 1 and times[0] == 1 and isinstance(
217                outcomes[0], Die):
218            return outcomes[0]
219
220        self = super(Population, cls).__new__(cls)
221        self._data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_die(outcomes, times)
222        return self

Constructor for a Die.

Don't confuse this with d():

  • Die([6]): A Die that always rolls the int 6.
  • d(6): A d6.

Also, don't confuse this with Pool():

  • Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]): A d6.
  • Pool([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]): A Pool of six dice that always rolls one of each number.

Here are some different ways of constructing a d6:

  • Just import it: from icepool import d6
  • Use the d() function: icepool.d(6)
  • Use a d6 that you already have: Die(d6) or Die([d6])
  • Mix a d3 and a d3+3: Die([d3, d3+3])
  • Use a dict: Die({1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, 6:1})
  • Give the faces as a sequence: Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])

All quantities must be non-negative, though they can be zero.

Several methods and functions foward **kwargs to this constructor. However, these only affect the construction of the returned or yielded dice. Any other implicit conversions of arguments or operands to dice will be done with the default keyword arguments.

EXPERIMENTAL: Use icepool.Again() to roll the dice again, usually with some modification. For example,

Die([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 + Again()])

would be an exploding d6. Use the again_depth parameter to control the maximum depth. again_depth does not apply to Reroll.

If the roll reaches the maximum depth, the again_end is used instead of rolling again. Options for again_end include:

  • No value (None), which will attempt to determine a zero value from the outcomes that don't involve Again.
  • A single outcome, or a Die.
  • Reroll, which will reroll any end roll involving Again.
  • You could also consider some sort of placeholder value such as math.inf.

Denominator: For a flat set of outcomes, the denominator is just the sum of the corresponding quantities. If the outcomes themselves have secondary denominators, then the overall denominator is the primary denominator times the LCM of the outcome denominators.

For example, Die([d3, d4, d6]) has a final denominator of 36: 3 for the primary selection between the three secondary dice, times 12 for the LCM of 3, 4, and 6.

Arguments:

  • outcomes: The faces of the Die. This can be one of the following:

    • A Mapping from outcomes to quantities.
    • A sequence of outcomes. Each element will have the same total quantity.

    Note that Die and Deck both count as Mappings. Each outcome may be one of the following:

    • A Mapping from outcomes to quantities. The outcomes of the Mapping will be "flattened" into the result. This option will be taken in preference to treating the Mapping itself as an outcome even if the Mapping itself is hashable and totally orderable. This means that Die and Deck will never be outcomes.

    • A tuple of outcomes. Operators on dice with tuple outcomes are performed element-wise. See Die.unary_op and Die.binary_op for details.

      Any tuple elements that are Mappings will expand the tuple according to their independent joint distribution. For example, (d6, d6) will expand to 36 ordered tuples with quantity 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a large number of outcomes.

    • str or bytes, which will be treated as a single outcome.
    • Any other sequence. Each element will be weighted equally.
    • icepool.Reroll, which will drop itself and the corresponding element of times from consideration. If inside a tuple, the tuple will be dropped.
    • Anything else will be treated as a single outcome. Each outcome must be hashable, and the set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion). The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case the corresponding quantities will be accumulated.
  • times: Multiplies the quantity of each element of outcomes. times can either be a sequence of the same length as outcomes or a single int to apply to all elements of outcomes.
Raises:
  • ValueError: None is not a valid outcome for a Die.
def unary_op(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> icepool.Die: 
224    def unary_op(self, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
225        """Performs the unary operation on the outcomes.
226
227        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
228        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
229        rather than an operator.
230
231        This is used for the standard unary operators
232        `-, +, abs, ~, round, trunc, floor, ceil`
233        as well as the additional methods
234        `zero, bool`.
235
236        This is NOT used for the `[]` operator; when used directly, this is
237        interpreted as a `Mapping` operation and returns the count corresponding
238        to a given outcome. See `marginals()` for applying the `[]` operator to
239        outcomes.
240
241        Returns:
242            A `Die` representing the result.
243
244        Raises:
245            ValueError: If tuples are of mismatched length.
246        """
247        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
248        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
249            new_outcome = unary_elementwise(outcome, op, *args, **kwargs)
250            data[new_outcome] += quantity
251        return icepool.Die(data)

Performs the unary operation on the outcomes.

Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use sub() rather than an operator.

This is used for the standard unary operators -, +, abs, ~, round, trunc, floor, ceil as well as the additional methods zero, bool.

This is NOT used for the [] operator; when used directly, this is interpreted as a Mapping operation and returns the count corresponding to a given outcome. See marginals() for applying the [] operator to outcomes.

Returns:

A Die representing the result.

Raises:
  • ValueError: If tuples are of mismatched length.
def binary_op( self, other: icepool.Die, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> icepool.Die: 
253    def binary_op(self, other: 'Die', op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> 'Die':
254        """Performs the operation on pairs of outcomes.
255
256        Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need
257        some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use `sub()`
258        rather than an operator.
259
260        By the time this is called, the other operand has already been
261        converted to a `Die`.
262
263        This is used for the standard binary operators
264        `+, -, *, /, //, %, **, <<, >>, &, |, ^`.
265        Note that `*` multiplies outcomes directly;
266        it is not the same as `@`, which rolls the right side multiple times,
267        or `d()`, which creates a standard die.
268
269        The comparators (`<, <=, >=, >, ==, !=, cmp`) use a linear algorithm
270        using the fact that outcomes are totally ordered.
271
272        `==` and `!=` additionally set the truth value of the `Die` according to
273        whether the dice themselves are the same or not.
274
275        The `@` operator does NOT use this method directly.
276        It rolls the left `Die`, which must have integer outcomes,
277        then rolls the right `Die` that many times and sums the outcomes.
278        Only the sum is performed element-wise.
279
280        Returns:
281            A `Die` representing the result.
282
283        Raises:
284            ValueError: If tuples are of mismatched length within one of the
285                dice or between the dice.
286        """
287        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
288        for (outcome_self,
289             quantity_self), (outcome_other,
290                              quantity_other) in itertools.product(
291                                  self.items(), other.items()):
292            new_outcome = binary_elementwise(outcome_self, outcome_other, op,
293                                             *args, **kwargs)
294            data[new_outcome] += quantity_self * quantity_other
295        return icepool.Die(data)

Performs the operation on pairs of outcomes.

Operations on tuples are performed elementwise recursively. If you need some other specific behavior, use your own outcome class, or use sub() rather than an operator.

By the time this is called, the other operand has already been converted to a Die.

This is used for the standard binary operators +, -, *, /, //, %, **, <<, >>, &, |, ^. Note that * multiplies outcomes directly; it is not the same as @, which rolls the right side multiple times, or d(), which creates a standard die.

The comparators (<, <=, >=, >, ==, !=, cmp) use a linear algorithm using the fact that outcomes are totally ordered.

== and != additionally set the truth value of the Die according to whether the dice themselves are the same or not.

The @ operator does NOT use this method directly. It rolls the left Die, which must have integer outcomes, then rolls the right Die that many times and sums the outcomes. Only the sum is performed element-wise.

Returns:

A Die representing the result.

Raises:
  • ValueError: If tuples are of mismatched length within one of the dice or between the dice.
def keys(self) -> icepool.CountsKeysView: 
299    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView:
300        return self._data.keys()

The outcomes within the population in sorted order.

def reroll( self, outcomes: Union[Callable[..., bool], Container, NoneType] = None, *extra_args, depth: int | None = None, star: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
329    def reroll(self,
330               outcomes: Callable[..., bool] | Container | None = None,
331               *extra_args,
332               depth: int | None = None,
333               star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
334        """Rerolls the given outcomes.
335
336        Args:
337            outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll. Options:
338                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
339                    should be rerolled.
340                * A container of outcomes to reroll.
341                * If not provided, the min outcome will be rerolled.
342            *extra_args: These will be supplied to `outcomes` as extra
343                positional arguments after the outcome argument(s).
344                `extra_args` can only be supplied if `outcomes` is callable.
345            depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
346                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
347            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
348                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
349                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
350
351        Returns:
352            A `Die` representing the reroll.
353            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
354
355        Raises:
356            ValueError: If `extra_args` are supplied with a non-callable `outcomes`.
357        """
358        if extra_args and not callable(outcomes):
359            raise ValueError(
360                'Extra positional arguments are only valid if outcomes is callable.'
361            )
362
363        if outcomes is None:
364            outcomes = {self.min_outcome()}
365        elif callable(outcomes):
366            if star:
367                outcomes = {
368                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
369                    if outcomes(*outcome, *extra_args)
370                }
371            else:
372                outcomes = {
373                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
374                    if outcomes(outcome, *extra_args)
375                }
376
377        if depth is None:
378            data = {
379                outcome: quantity
380                for outcome, quantity in self.items()
381                if outcome not in outcomes
382            }
383        else:
384            total_reroll_quantity = sum(
385                quantity for outcome, quantity in self.items()
386                if outcome in outcomes)
387            rerollable_factor = total_reroll_quantity**depth
388            stop_factor = (self.denominator()**depth +
389                           total_reroll_quantity**depth)
390            data = {
391                outcome:
392                (rerollable_factor *
393                 quantity if outcome in outcomes else stop_factor * quantity)
394                for outcome, quantity in self.items()
395            }
396        return icepool.Die(data)

Rerolls the given outcomes.

Arguments:
  • outcomes: Selects which outcomes to reroll. Options:
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be rerolled.
    • A container of outcomes to reroll.
    • If not provided, the min outcome will be rerolled.
  • *extra_args: These will be supplied to outcomes as extra positional arguments after the outcome argument(s). extra_args can only be supplied if outcomes is callable.
  • depth: The maximum number of times to reroll. If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the outcomes function. If outcomes is not a callable, this has no effect.
Returns:

A Die representing the reroll. If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.

Raises:
  • ValueError: If extra_args are supplied with a non-callable outcomes.

def truncate(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> icepool.Die: 
451    def truncate(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
452        """Truncates the outcomes of this `Die` to the given range.
453
454        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
455        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.
456
457        This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range.
458        If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint,
459        use `clip()`.
460
461        Not to be confused with `trunc(die)`, which performs integer truncation
462        on each outcome.
463        """
464        if min_outcome is not None:
465            start = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), min_outcome)
466        else:
467            start = None
468        if max_outcome is not None:
469            stop = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), max_outcome)
470        else:
471            stop = None
472        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items()[start:stop]}
473        return icepool.Die(data)

Truncates the outcomes of this Die to the given range.

The endpoints are included in the result if applicable. If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.

This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range. If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint, use clip().

Not to be confused with trunc(die), which performs integer truncation on each outcome.

def clip(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> icepool.Die: 
475    def clip(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die':
476        """Clips the outcomes of this `Die` to the given values.
477
478        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
479        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be clipped.
480
481        This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range;
482        the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range.
483        This will typically cause some quantity to bunch up at the endpoint.
484        If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use `truncate()`.
485        """
486        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
487        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
488            if min_outcome is not None and outcome <= min_outcome:
489                data[min_outcome] += quantity
490            elif max_outcome is not None and outcome >= max_outcome:
491                data[max_outcome] += quantity
492            else:
493                data[outcome] += quantity
494        return icepool.Die(data)

This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range; the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range. This will typically cause some quantity to bunch up at the endpoint. If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use truncate().
