def sub( self, repl: Union[Callable, Mapping], /, repeat: int | None = 1, star: int = 0, again_depth: int = 1, again_end=None) -> icepool.Die: 
556    def sub(self,
557            repl: Callable | Mapping,
558            /,
559            repeat: int | None = 1,
560            star: int = 0,
561            again_depth: int = 1,
562            again_end=None) -> 'Die':
563        """Changes outcomes of the `Die` to other outcomes.
564
565        You can think of this as `sub`stituting outcomes of this `Die` for other
566        outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a `sub`routine based on the roll of
567        this `Die`.
568
569        EXPERIMENTAL: `Again`, `again_depth`, and `again_end` can be used as the
570        `Die()` constructor. It is not advised to use these with `repeat` other
571        than 1.
572
573        Args:
574            repl: One of the following:
575                * A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
576                * A map from old outcomes to new outcomes.
577                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
578                The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes.
579                The special value `icepool.Reroll` will reroll that old outcome.
580            repeat: `sub()` will be repeated with the same argument on the
581                result this many times.
582
583                EXPERIMENTAL: If set to `None`, the result will be as if `sub()`
584                    were repeated an infinite number of times. In this case, the
585                    result will be in simplest form.
586            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes of `self` will be unpacked as
587                `*outcome` before giving it to the `repl` function. `extra_dice`
588                are not unpacked. If `repl` is not a callable, this has no
589                effect.
590            again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
591            again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
592
593        Returns:
594            The `Die` after the modification.
595        """
596
597        if repeat == 0:
598            return self
599
600        # Convert to a single-argument function.
601        if callable(repl):
602            if star:
603
604                def transition_function(outcome):
605                    return repl(*outcome)
606            else:
607
608                def transition_function(outcome):
609                    return repl(outcome)
610        else:
611            # repl is a mapping.
612            def transition_function(outcome):
613                if outcome in repl:
614                    return repl[outcome]
615                else:
616                    return outcome
617
618        if repeat is not None:
619            result = self
620            for _ in range(repeat):
621                result = icepool.apply(transition_function,
622                                       result,
623                                       again_depth=again_depth,
624                                       again_end=again_end)
625            return result
626        else:
627            # Infinite repeat.
628            return icepool.markov_chain.absorbing_markov_chain(
629                self, transition_function)

Changes outcomes of the Die to other outcomes.

You can think of this as substituting outcomes of this Die for other outcomes or dice. Or, as executing a subroutine based on the roll of this Die.

EXPERIMENTAL: Again, again_depth, and again_end can be used as the Die() constructor. It is not advised to use these with repeat other than 1.

Arguments:
  • repl: One of the following:
    • A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
    • A map from old outcomes to new outcomes. Unmapped old outcomes stay the same. The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes. The special value icepool.Reroll will reroll that old outcome.

  • repeat: sub() will be repeated with the same argument on the result this many times.

    EXPERIMENTAL: If set to None, the result will be as if sub() were repeated an infinite number of times. In this case, the result will be in simplest form.

  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes of self will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the repl function. extra_dice are not unpacked. If repl is not a callable, this has no effect.
  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
Returns:

The Die after the modification.

def explode( self, outcomes: Union[Callable[..., bool], Container, NoneType] = None, *extra_args, depth: int = 9, end=None, star: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
631    def explode(self,
632                outcomes: Container | Callable[..., bool] | None = None,
633                *extra_args,
634                depth: int = 9,
635                end=None,
636                star: int = 0) -> 'Die':
637        """Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.
638
639        Args:
640            outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
641                * An container of outcomes to explode.
642                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
643                    should be exploded.
644                * If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
645            *extra_args: These will be supplied to `outcomes` as extra
646                positional arguments after the outcome argument(s).
647                `extra_args` can only be supplied if `outcomes` is callable.
648            depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll.
649                If not supplied, a default value will be used.
650            end: Once depth is reached, further explosions will be treated
651                as this value. By default, a zero value will be used.
652            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as
653                `*outcome` before giving it to the `outcomes` function.
654                If `outcomes` is not a callable, this has no effect.
655
656        Raises:
657            ValueError: If `extra_args` are supplied with a non-callable `outcomes`.
658        """
659        if extra_args and not callable(outcomes):
660            raise ValueError(
661                'Extra positional arguments are only valid if outcomes is callable.'
662            )
663
664        if outcomes is None:
665            outcomes = {self.max_outcome()}
666        elif callable(outcomes):
667            if star:
668                outcomes = {
669                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
670                    if outcomes(*outcome, *extra_args)
671                }
672            else:
673                outcomes = {
674                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
675                    if outcomes(outcome, *extra_args)
676                }
677        else:
678            if not outcomes:
679                return self
680
681        if depth < 0:
682            raise ValueError('depth cannot be negative.')
683        elif depth == 0:
684            return self
685
686        def sub_func(outcome):
687            if outcome in outcomes:
688                return outcome + icepool.Again()
689            else:
690                return outcome
691
692        return self.sub(sub_func, again_depth=depth, again_end=end)

Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.

Arguments:
  • outcomes: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
    • An container of outcomes to explode.
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be exploded.
    • If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
  • *extra_args: These will be supplied to outcomes as extra positional arguments after the outcome argument(s). extra_args can only be supplied if outcomes is callable.
  • depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll. If not supplied, a default value will be used.
  • end: Once depth is reached, further explosions will be treated as this value. By default, a zero value will be used.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the outcomes function. If outcomes is not a callable, this has no effect.
Raises:
  • ValueError: If extra_args are supplied with a non-callable outcomes.

def pool(self, rolls: Union[int, Sequence[int]], /) -> icepool.Pool: 
783    def pool(self, rolls: int | Sequence[int], /) -> 'icepool.Pool':
784        """Creates a `Pool` from this `Die`.
785
786        You might subscript the pool immediately afterwards, e.g.
787        `d6.pool(5)[-1, ..., 1]` takes the difference between the highest and
788        lowest of 5d6.
789
790        Args:
791            rolls: The number of copies of this `Die` to put in the pool.
792                Or, a sequence of one `int` per die acting as
793                `sorted_roll_counts`. Note that `...` cannot be used in the
794                argument to this method, as the argument determines the size of
795                the pool.
796        """
797        if isinstance(rolls, int):
798            return icepool.Pool({self: rolls})
799        else:
800            pool_size = len(rolls)
801            return icepool.Pool({self: pool_size})[rolls]

def keep_lowest(self, rolls: int, /, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
803    def keep_lowest(self, rolls: int, /, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'Die':
804        """Roll several of this `Die` and sum the sorted results from the lowest.
805
806        Args:
807            rolls: The number of dice to roll. All dice will have the same
808                outcomes as `self`.
809            keep: The number of dice to keep.
810            drop: If provided, this many lowest dice will be dropped before
811                keeping.
812
813        Returns:
814            A `Die` representing the probability distribution of the sum.
815        """
816        if keep == 1 and drop == 0:
817            return self._keep_lowest_single(rolls)
818
819        start = drop if drop > 0 else None
820        stop = keep + (drop or 0)
821        sorted_roll_counts = slice(start, stop)
822        return self.pool(rolls)[sorted_roll_counts].sum()

921        E.g. `0` for a `Die` whose outcomes are `int`s.
922        """
923        return self.zero().outcomes()[0]

def cmp(self, other) -> icepool.Die: 
1193    def cmp(self, other) -> 'Die':
1194        """A `Die` with outcomes 1, -1, and 0.
1195
1196        The quantities are equal to the positive outcome of `self > other`,
1197        `self < other`, and the remainder respectively.
1198
1199        This will include all three outcomes even if they have zero quantity.
1200        """
1201        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1202
1203        data = {}
1204
1205        lt = self < other
1206        if True in lt:
1207            data[-1] = lt[True]
1208        eq = self == other
1209        if True in eq:
1210            data[0] = eq[True]
1211        gt = self > other
1212        if True in gt:
1213            data[1] = gt[True]
1214
1215        return Die(data)

A Die with outcomes 1, -1, and 0.

The quantities are equal to the positive outcome of self > other, self < other, and the remainder respectively.

This will include all three outcomes even if they have zero quantity.

def sign(self) -> icepool.Die: 
1227    def sign(self) -> 'Die':
1228        """Outcomes become 1 if greater than `zero()`, -1 if less than `zero()`, and 0 otherwise.
1229
1230        Note that for `float`s, +0.0, -0.0, and nan all become 0.
1231        """
1232        return self.unary_op(Die._sign)

Outcomes become 1 if greater than zero(), -1 if less than zero(), and 0 otherwise.

Note that for floats, +0.0, -0.0, and nan all become 0.

def equals(self, other, *, simplify=False): 
1269    def equals(self, other, *, simplify=False):
1270        """`True` iff both dice have the same outcomes and quantities.
1271
1272        This is `False` if `other` is not a `Die`, even if it would convert
1273        to an equal `Die`.
1274
1275        Truth value does NOT matter.
1276
1277        If one `Die` has a zero-quantity outcome and the other `Die` does not
1278        contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.
1279
1280        The `==` and `!=` operators have a dual purpose; they return a `Die`
1281        with a truth value determined by this method.
1282        Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of
1283        these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested
1284        in the `Die` value or the truth value.
1285
1286        Args:
1287            simplify: If `True`, the dice will be simplified before comparing.
1288                Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not `equals()` to a 1:1 coin.
1289        """
1290        if not isinstance(other, Die):
1291            return False
1292
1293        if simplify:
1294            return self.simplify().key_tuple() == other.simplify().key_tuple()
1295        else:
1296            return self.key_tuple() == other.key_tuple()

True iff both dice have the same outcomes and quantities.

This is False if other is not a Die, even if it would convert to an equal Die.

Truth value does NOT matter.

If one Die has a zero-quantity outcome and the other Die does not contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.

The == and != operators have a dual purpose; they return a Die with a truth value determined by this method. Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested in the Die value or the truth value.

Arguments:
  • simplify: If True, the dice will be simplified before comparing. Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not equals() to a 1:1 coin.

class Population(abc.ABC, typing.Mapping[typing.Any, int]): 
 22class Population(ABC, Mapping[Any, int]):
 23    """A mapping from outcomes to `int` quantities.
 24
 25    Outcomes with each instance must be hashable and totally orderable.
 26
 27    Subclasses include `Die` and `Deck`.
 28    """

 30    # Abstract methods.
 31
 32    @abstractmethod
 33    def _new_type(self) -> type:
 34        """The type to use when constructing a new instance."""
 35
 36    @abstractmethod
 37    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView:
 38        """The outcomes within the population in sorted order."""
 39
 40    @abstractmethod
 41    def values(self) -> CountsValuesView:
 42        """The quantities within the population in outcome order."""

 44    @abstractmethod
 45    def items(self) -> CountsItemsView:

 48    # Outcomes.
 49
 50    def outcomes(self) -> CountsKeysView:
 51        """The sorted outcomes of the mapping.
 52
 53        These are also the `keys` of the mapping.
 54        Prefer to use the name `outcomes`.
 55        """
 56        return self.keys()
 57
 58    @cached_property
 59    def _outcome_len(self) -> int | None:
 60        result = None
 61        for outcome in self.outcomes():
 62            try:
 63                if result is None:
 64                    result = len(outcome)
 65                elif len(outcome) != result:
 66                    return None
 67            except TypeError:
 68                return None
 69        return result
 70
 71    def outcome_len(self) -> int | None:
 72        """The common length of tuple outcomes.
 73
 74        This is `None` if outcomes are not tuples,
 75        or if there are tuples of different lengths.
 76        """
 77        return self._outcome_len
 78
 79    def is_empty(self) -> bool:
 80        """`True` iff this mapping has no outcomes. """
 81        return len(self) == 0
 82
 83    def min_outcome(self):
 84        """The least outcome."""
 85        return self.outcomes()[0]
 86
 87    def max_outcome(self):
 88        """The greatest outcome."""
 89        return self.outcomes()[-1]
 90
 91    def nearest_le(self, outcome):
 92        """The nearest outcome that is <= the argument.
 93
 94        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
 95        """
 96        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
 97        if index < 0:
 98            return None
 99        return self.outcomes()[index]
100
101    def nearest_ge(self, outcome):
102        """The nearest outcome that is >= the argument.
103
104        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
105        """
106        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
107        if index >= len(self):
108            return None
109        return self.outcomes()[index]

111    # Quantities.
112
113    def quantities(self) -> CountsValuesView:
114        """The quantities of the mapping in sorted order.
115
116        These are also the `values` of the mapping.
117        Prefer to use the name `quantities`.
118        """
119        return self.values()
120
121    @cached_property
122    def _denominator(self) -> int:
123        return sum(self.values())
124
125    def denominator(self) -> int:
126        """The sum of all quantities (e.g. weights or duplicates).
127
128        For the number of unique outcomes, including those with zero quantity,
129        use `len()`.
130        """
131        return self._denominator

135    def has_zero_quantities(self) -> bool:
136        """`True` iff `self` contains at least one outcome with zero quantity. """
137        return 0 in self.values()

139    @cached_property
140    def _quantities_le(self) -> Sequence[int]:
141        return tuple(itertools.accumulate(self.values()))
142
143    def quantities_le(self) -> Sequence[int]:
144        """The quantity <= each outcome in order. """
145        return self._quantities_le
146
147    @cached_property
148    def _quantities_ge(self) -> Sequence[int]:
149        return tuple(
150            itertools.accumulate(self.values()[:-1],
151                                 operator.sub,
152                                 initial=self.denominator()))
153
154    def quantities_ge(self) -> Sequence[int]:
155        """The quantity >= each outcome in order. """
156        return self._quantities_ge
157
158    def quantity(self, outcome) -> int:
159        """The quantity of a single outcome, or 0 if not present. """
160        return self.get(outcome, 0)
161
162    def quantity_ne(self, outcome) -> int:
163        """The quantity != a single outcome. """
164        return self.denominator() - self.quantity(outcome)
165
166    def quantity_le(self, outcome) -> int:
167        """The quantity <= a single outcome. """
168        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
169        if index < 0:
170            return 0
171        return self.quantities_le()[index]
172
173    def quantity_lt(self, outcome) -> int:
174        """The quantity < a single outcome. """
175        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
176        if index < 0:
177            return 0
178        return self.quantities_le()[index]
179
180    def quantity_ge(self, outcome) -> int:
181        """The quantity >= a single outcome. """
182        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
183        if index >= len(self):
184            return 0
185        return self.quantities_ge()[index]
186
187    def quantity_gt(self, outcome) -> int:
188        """The quantity > a single outcome. """
189        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome)
190        if index >= len(self):
191            return 0
192        return self.quantities_ge()[index]

194    # Probabilities.
195
196    @cached_property
197    def _probabilities(self):
198        return tuple(v / self.denominator() for v in self.values())
199
200    def probabilities(self, percent: bool = False):
201        """The probability of each outcome in order.
202
203        Also known as the probability mass function (PMF).
204
205        Args:
206            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
207                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
208        """
209        if percent:
210            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._probabilities)
211        else:
212            return self._probabilities
213
214    @cached_property
215    def _probabilities_le(self) -> Sequence[float]:
216        return tuple(
217            quantity / self.denominator() for quantity in self.quantities_le())
218
219    def probabilities_le(self, percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
220        """The probability of rolling <= each outcome in order.
221
222        Also known as the cumulative distribution function (CDF),
223        though this term is ambigiuous whether it is < or <=.
224
225        Args:
226            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
227                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
228        """
229        if percent:
230            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._probabilities_le)
231        else:
232            return self._probabilities_le
233
234    @cached_property
235    def _probabilities_ge(self) -> Sequence[float]:
236        return tuple(
237            quantity / self.denominator() for quantity in self.quantities_ge())
238
239    def probabilities_ge(self, percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
240        """The probability of rolling >= each outcome in order.
241
242        Also known as the survival function (SF) or
243        complementary cumulative distribution function (CCDF),
244        though these term are ambigiuous whether they are is > or >=.
245
246        Args:
247            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
248                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
249        """
250        if percent:
251            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in self._probabilities_ge)
252        else:
253            return self._probabilities_ge
254
255    def probabilities_lt(self, percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
256        """The probability of rolling < each outcome in order.
257
258        Args:
259            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
260                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
261        """
262        if percent:
263            return tuple(100.0 * (1.0 - x) for x in self._probabilities_ge)
264        else:
265            return tuple((1.0 - x) for x in self._probabilities_ge)
266
267    def probabilities_gt(self, percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
268        """The probability of rolling > each outcome in order.
269
270        Args:
271            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
272                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
273        """
274        if percent:
275            return tuple(100.0 * (1.0 - x) for x in self._probabilities_le)
276        else:
277            return tuple((1.0 - x) for x in self._probabilities_le)
278
279    def probability(self, outcome) -> float:
280        """The probability of a single outcome, or 0.0 if not present. """
281        return self.quantity(outcome) / self.denominator()
282
283    # Scalar statistics.
284
285    def mode(self) -> tuple:
286        """A tuple containing the most common outcome(s) of the population.
287
288        These are sorted from lowest to highest.
289        """
290        return tuple(outcome for outcome, quantity in self.items()
291                     if quantity == self.modal_quantity())
292
293    def modal_quantity(self) -> int:
294        """The highest quantity of any single outcome. """
295        return max(self.quantities())
296
297    def kolmogorov_smirnov(self, other):
298        """KolmogorovSmirnov statistic. The maximum absolute difference between CDFs. """
299        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
300        return max(
301            abs(a - b)
302            for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))
303
304    def cramer_von_mises(self, other):
305        """Cramr-von Mises statistic. The sum-of-squares difference between CDFs. """
306        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
307        return sum((a - b)**2
308                   for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))
309
310    def median(self):
311        """The median, taking the mean in case of a tie.
312
313        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
314        in this case, use `median_left` or `median_right` instead.
315        """
316        return self.quantile(1, 2)
317
318    def median_left(self):
319        """The median, taking the lesser in case of a tie."""
320        return self.quantile_left(1, 2)
321
322    def median_right(self):
323        """The median, taking the greater in case of a tie."""
324        return self.quantile_right(1, 2)
325
326    def quantile(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
327        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the mean in case of a tie.
328
329        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
330        in this case, use `quantile_left` or `quantile_right` instead.
331        """
332        return (self.quantile_left(n, d) + self.quantile_right(n, d)) / 2
333
334    def quantile_left(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
335        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the lesser in case of a tie."""
336        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.quantities_le(),
337                                   (n * self.denominator() + d - 1) // d)
338        if index >= len(self):
339            return self.max_outcome()
340        return self.outcomes()[index]
341
342    def quantile_right(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
343        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the greater in case of a tie."""
344        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(),
345                                    n * self.denominator() // d)
346        if index >= len(self):
347            return self.max_outcome()
348        return self.outcomes()[index]
349
350    def mean(self):
351        return sum(outcome * quantity
352                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
353
354    def variance(self):
355        """This is the population variance, not the sample variance."""
356        mean = self.mean()
357        mean_of_squares = sum(
358            quantity * outcome**2
359            for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
360        return mean_of_squares - mean * mean
361
362    def standard_deviation(self):
363        return math.sqrt(self.variance())
364
365    sd = standard_deviation
366
367    def standardized_moment(self, k: int):
368        sd = self.standard_deviation()
369        mean = self.mean()
370        ev = sum(p * (outcome - mean)**k
371                 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.probabilities()))
372        return ev / (sd**k)
373
374    def skewness(self):
375        return self.standardized_moment(3.0)
376
377    def excess_kurtosis(self):
378        return self.standardized_moment(4.0) - 3.0
379
380    # Joint statistics.
381
382    class _Marginals(Sequence[P]):
383        """Helper class for implementing `marginals()`."""
384
385        _population: P
386
387        def __init__(self, population: P, /):
388            self._population = population
389
390        def __len__(self) -> int:
391            """The minimum len() of all outcomes."""
392            return min(len(x) for x in self._population.outcomes())
393
394        @overload
395        def __getitem__(self, dims: int, /) -> P:
396            ...
397
398        @overload
399        def __getitem__(self, dims: slice, /) -> Sequence[P]:
400            ...
401
402        def __getitem__(self, dims: int | slice, /) -> P | Sequence[P]:
403            """Marginalizes the given dimensions."""
404            return self._population.unary_op_non_elementwise(
405                operator.getitem, dims)
406
407    @property
408    def marginals(self: P) -> Sequence[P]:
409        """A property that applies the `[]` operator to outcomes.
410
411        This is not performed elementwise on tuples, so that this can be used
412        to slice tuple outcomes. For example, `population.marginals[:2]` will
413        marginalize the first two elements of tuples.
414        """
415        return Population._Marginals(self)
416
417    def unary_op_non_elementwise(self: P, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> P:
418        """As `unary_op()`, but not elementwise.
419
420        This is used for `marginals()`.
421        """
422        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
423        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
424            new_outcome = op(outcome, *args, **kwargs)
425            data[new_outcome] += quantity
426        return self._new_type()(data)
427
428    def covariance(self, i: int, j: int):
429        mean_i = self.marginals[i].mean()
430        mean_j = self.marginals[j].mean()
431        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * quantity
432                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
433
434    def correlation(self, i: int, j: int):
435        sd_i = self.marginals[i].standard_deviation()
436        sd_j = self.marginals[j].standard_deviation()
437        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)
438
439    def sample(self):
440        """A single random sample from this population.
441
442        Note that this is always "with replacement" even for `Deck` since
443        instances are immutable.
444
445        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
446        secure.
447        """
448        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
449        r = random.randrange(self.denominator())
450        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(), r)
451        return self.outcomes()[index]
452
453    def format(self, format_spec: str, **kwargs) -> str:
454        """Formats this mapping as a string.
455
456        `format_spec` should start with the output format,
457        which is either `md` (Markdown) or `csv` (comma-separated values),
458        followed by a ':' character.
459
460        After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:
461
462        * `o`: Outcomes.
463        * `*o`: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
464        * `q==`, `q<=`, `q>=`: Quantities ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
465        * `p==`, `p<=`, `p>=`: Probabilities (0-1) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
466        * `%==`, `%<=`, `%>=`: Probabilities (0%-100%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
467
468        Columns may optionally be separated using ` ` (space) or `|` characters.
469
470        The default is `'md:*o|q==|%=='`, with the quantity column being omitted
471        if any quantity exceeds 10**30.
472        """
473        if len(format_spec) == 0:
474            format_spec = 'md:*o'
475            if not self.is_empty() and self.modal_quantity() < 10**30:
476                format_spec += 'q=='
477            format_spec += '%=='
478
479        format_spec = format_spec.replace('|', '')
480
481        output_format, format_spec = format_spec.split(':')
482        if output_format == 'md':
483            return icepool.format.markdown(self, format_spec)
484        elif output_format == 'csv':
485            return icepool.format.csv(self, format_spec, **kwargs)
486        else:
487            raise ValueError(f"Unsupported output format '{output_format}'")
488
489    def __format__(self, format_spec: str) -> str:
490        return self.format(format_spec)
491
492    def __str__(self) -> str:
493        return f'{self}'

def kolmogorov_smirnov(self, other): 
297    def kolmogorov_smirnov(self, other):
298        """KolmogorovSmirnov statistic. The maximum absolute difference between CDFs. """
299        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
300        return max(
301            abs(a - b)
302            for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))

305        """Cramr-von Mises statistic. The sum-of-squares difference between CDFs. """

307        return sum((a - b)**2
308                   for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))

def quantile_left(self, n: int, d: int = 100): 
334    def quantile_left(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
335        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the lesser in case of a tie."""
336        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.quantities_le(),
337                                   (n * self.denominator() + d - 1) // d)
338        if index >= len(self):
339            return self.max_outcome()
340        return self.outcomes()[index]

The outcome n / d of the way through the CDF, taking the lesser in case of a tie.

def quantile_right(self, n: int, d: int = 100): 
342    def quantile_right(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
343        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the greater in case of a tie."""
344        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(),
345                                    n * self.denominator() // d)
346        if index >= len(self):
347            return self.max_outcome()
348        return self.outcomes()[index]

def mean(self): 
350    def mean(self):
351        return sum(outcome * quantity
352                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
def variance(self): 
354    def variance(self):
355        """This is the population variance, not the sample variance."""
356        mean = self.mean()
357        mean_of_squares = sum(
358            quantity * outcome**2
359            for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
360        return mean_of_squares - mean * mean

This is the population variance, not the sample variance.

362    def standard_deviation(self):

def standardized_moment(self, k: int): 
367    def standardized_moment(self, k: int):
368        sd = self.standard_deviation()
369        mean = self.mean()
370        ev = sum(p * (outcome - mean)**k
371                 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.probabilities()))
372        return ev / (sd**k)
def skewness(self):

marginals: Sequence[~P]

A property that applies the [] operator to outcomes.

This is not performed elementwise on tuples, so that this can be used to slice tuple outcomes. For example, population.marginals[:2] will marginalize the first two elements of tuples.

def unary_op_non_elementwise(self: ~P, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> ~P: 
417    def unary_op_non_elementwise(self: P, op: Callable, *args, **kwargs) -> P:
418        """As `unary_op()`, but not elementwise.
419
420        This is used for `marginals()`.
421        """
422        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
423        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
424            new_outcome = op(outcome, *args, **kwargs)
425            data[new_outcome] += quantity
426        return self._new_type()(data)

As unary_op(), but not elementwise.

This is used for marginals().

def covariance(self, i: int, j: int): 
428    def covariance(self, i: int, j: int):
429        mean_i = self.marginals[i].mean()
430        mean_j = self.marginals[j].mean()
431        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * quantity
432                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
def correlation(self, i: int, j: int): 
434    def correlation(self, i: int, j: int):
435        sd_i = self.marginals[i].standard_deviation()
436        sd_j = self.marginals[j].standard_deviation()
437        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)
def sample(self): 
439    def sample(self):
440        """A single random sample from this population.
441
442        Note that this is always "with replacement" even for `Deck` since
443        instances are immutable.
444
445        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
446        secure.
447        """
448        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
449        r = random.randrange(self.denominator())
450        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(), r)
451        return self.outcomes()[index]

def format(self, format_spec: str, **kwargs) -> str: 
453    def format(self, format_spec: str, **kwargs) -> str:
454        """Formats this mapping as a string.
455
456        `format_spec` should start with the output format,
457        which is either `md` (Markdown) or `csv` (comma-separated values),
458        followed by a ':' character.
459
460        After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:
461
462        * `o`: Outcomes.
463        * `*o`: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
464        * `q==`, `q<=`, `q>=`: Quantities ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
465        * `p==`, `p<=`, `p>=`: Probabilities (0-1) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
466        * `%==`, `%<=`, `%>=`: Probabilities (0%-100%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
467
468        Columns may optionally be separated using ` ` (space) or `|` characters.
469
470        The default is `'md:*o|q==|%=='`, with the quantity column being omitted
471        if any quantity exceeds 10**30.
472        """
473        if len(format_spec) == 0:
474            format_spec = 'md:*o'
475            if not self.is_empty() and self.modal_quantity() < 10**30:
476                format_spec += 'q=='
477            format_spec += '%=='
478
479        format_spec = format_spec.replace('|', '')
480
481        output_format, format_spec = format_spec.split(':')
482        if output_format == 'md':
483            return icepool.format.markdown(self, format_spec)
484        elif output_format == 'csv':
485            return icepool.format.csv(self, format_spec, **kwargs)
486        else:
487            raise ValueError(f"Unsupported output format '{output_format}'")

Formats this mapping as a string.

format_spec should start with the output format, which is either md (Markdown) or csv (comma-separated values), followed by a ':' character.

After this, zero or more columns should follow. Options are:

  • o: Outcomes.
  • *o: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
  • q==, q<=, q>=: Quantities ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
  • p==, p<=, p>=: Probabilities (0-1) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
  • %==, %<=, %>=: Probabilities (0%-100%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.

Columns may optionally be separated using (space) or | characters.

The default is 'md:*o|q==|%==', with the quantity column being omitted if any quantity exceeds 10**30.

class Again: 
 12class Again():
 13    """EXPERIMENTAL: A placeholder value used to indicate that the die should be rolled again with some modification.
 14
 15    Examples:
 16
 17    * `Again()` + 6: Roll again and add 6.
 18    * `Again(lambda x: x + 6)`: Another way of doing the same thing.
 19    * `Again()` + `Again()`: Roll again twice and sum.
 20
 21    This can also be used as part of a return value with functions such as
 22    `Die.sub()`, though I don't recommend getting too fancy---it can get
 23    confusing very quickly.
 24    """
 25
 26    def __init__(self, func: Callable | None = None, /, *args):
 27        """Creates an `Again` placeholder from the given function and args.
 28
 29        Any of the args may themselves be instances of `Again`. These are
 30        considered to be at the same level for purposes of `again_depth`.
 31
 32        The supplied function will be called with the given args, except any
 33        arguments of type `Again` will have resolved to the `Die` resulting
 34        from rolling again.
 35        """
 36        self._func = func
 37        self._args = args
 38
 39    def _evaluate_arg(self, arg, die: 'icepool.Die'):
 40        if isinstance(arg, Again):
 41            return arg._evaluate(die)
 42        else:
 43            return arg
 44
 45    def _evaluate(self, die: 'icepool.Die'):
 46        """Recursively substitutes the provided `Die` for the `Again` placeholders."""
 47        if self._func is None:
 48            return die
 49        else:
 50            return self._func(
 51                *(self._evaluate_arg(arg, die) for arg in self._args))
 52

 56        return Again(operator.neg, self)

147    # Hashing and equality.
148
149    def __eq__(self, other):
150        if not isinstance(other, Again):
151            return False
152        return self is other or self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple

def from_cumulative_quantities( outcomes: Sequence, cumulative_quantities: Sequence[int], *, reverse: bool = False) -> icepool.Die: 
 83def from_cumulative_quantities(outcomes: Sequence,
 84                               cumulative_quantities: Sequence[int],
 85                               *,
 86                               reverse: bool = False) -> 'icepool.Die':
 87    """Constructs a `Die` from a sequence of cumulative quantities.
 88
 89    Args:
 90        outcomes: The outcomes of the resulting die. Sorted order is recommended
 91            but not necessary.
 92        cumulative_quantities: The cumulative quantities (inclusive) of the
 93            outcomes in the order they are given to this function.
 94        reverse: Iff true, both of the arguments will be reversed. This allows
 95            e.g. constructing using a survival distribution.
 96    """
 97
 98    prev = 0
 99    d = {}
100    for outcome, quantity in zip((reversed(outcomes) if reverse else outcomes),
101                                 (reversed(cumulative_quantities)
102                                  if reverse else cumulative_quantities)):
103        d[outcome] = quantity - prev
104        prev = quantity
105    return icepool.Die(d)

Constructs a Die from a sequence of cumulative quantities.

Arguments:
  • outcomes: The outcomes of the resulting die. Sorted order is recommended but not necessary.
  • cumulative_quantities: The cumulative quantities (inclusive) of the outcomes in the order they are given to this function.
  • reverse: Iff true, both of the arguments will be reversed. This allows e.g. constructing using a survival distribution.
def from_rv(rv, outcomes: Sequence[int | float], denominator: int, **kwargs): 
108def from_rv(rv, outcomes: Sequence[int | float], denominator: int, **kwargs):
109    """Constructs a `Die` from a rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
110    Args:
111        rv: A rv object (as `scipy.stats`).
112        outcomes: An iterable of `int`s or `float`s that will be the outcomes
113            of the resulting `Die`.
114            If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be `int`s.
115        denominator: The denominator of the resulting `Die` will be set to this.
116        **kwargs: These will be forwarded to `rv.cdf()`.
117    """
118    if hasattr(rv, 'pdf'):
119        # Continuous distributions use midpoints.
120        midpoints = [(a + b) / 2 for a, b in zip(outcomes[:-1], outcomes[1:])]
121        cdf = rv.cdf(midpoints, **kwargs)
122        quantities_le = tuple(
123            int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf) + (denominator,)
124    else:
125        cdf = rv.cdf(outcomes, **kwargs)
126        quantities_le = tuple(int(round(x * denominator)) for x in cdf)
127    return from_cumulative_quantities(outcomes, quantities_le)

Constructs a Die from a rv object (as scipy.stats).

Arguments:
  • rv: A rv object (as scipy.stats).
  • outcomes: An iterable of ints or floats that will be the outcomes of the resulting Die. If the distribution is discrete, outcomes must be ints.
  • denominator: The denominator of the resulting Die will be set to this.
  • **kwargs: These will be forwarded to rv.cdf().

def reduce( func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None, again_depth: int = 1, again_end=None) -> icepool.Die: 
173def reduce(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any],
174           dice,
175           *,
176           initial=None,
177           again_depth: int = 1,
178           again_end=None) -> 'icepool.Die':
179    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice.
180
181    Analogous to
182    [`functools.reduce()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.reduce).
183
184    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
185
186    Args:
187        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
188            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
189        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
190        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
191            of dice.
192        again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
193        again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
194    """
195    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
196    iter_dice = iter(dice)
197    if initial is not None:
198        result = icepool.implicit_convert_to_die(initial)
199    else:
200        result = next(iter_dice)
201    for die in iter_dice:
202        result = apply(func,
203                       result,
204                       die,
205                       again_depth=again_depth,
206                       again_end=again_end)
207    return result

Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice.

Analogous to functools.reduce().

The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.

Arguments:
  • func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments, which are an outcome from each of two dice.
  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
def accumulate( func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any], dice, *, initial=None, again_depth: int = 1, again_end=None) -> Generator[icepool.Die, NoneType, NoneType]: 
210def accumulate(func: Callable[[Any, Any], Any],
211               dice,
212               *,
213               initial=None,
214               again_depth: int = 1,
215               again_end=None) -> Generator['icepool.Die', None, None]:
216    """Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.
217
218    Analogous to
219    [`itertools.accumulate()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/itertools.html#itertools.accumulate)
220    , though with no default function and
221    the same parameter order as `reduce()`.
222
223    The number of results is equal to the number of elements of `dice`, with
224    one additional element if `initial` is provided.
225
226    The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.
227
228    Args:
229        func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments,
230            which are an outcome from each of two dice.
231        dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
232        initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence
233            of dice.
234        again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
235        again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
236    """
237    # Conversion to dice is not necessary since apply() takes care of that.
238    iter_dice = iter(dice)
239    if initial is not None:
240        result = icepool.implicit_convert_to_die(initial)
241    else:
242        try:
243            result = next(iter_dice)
244        except StopIteration:
245            return
246    yield result
247    for die in iter_dice:
248        result = apply(func,
249                       result,
250                       die,
251                       again_depth=again_depth,
252                       again_end=again_end)
253        yield result

Applies a function of two arguments cumulatively to a sequence of dice, yielding each result in turn.

Analogous to itertools.accumulate() , though with no default function and the same parameter order as reduce().

The number of results is equal to the number of elements of dice, with one additional element if initial is provided.

The function is applied non-elementwise to tuple outcomes.

Arguments:
  • func: The function to apply. The function should take two arguments, which are an outcome from each of two dice.
  • dice: A sequence of dice to apply the function to, from left to right.
  • initial: If provided, this will be placed at the front of the sequence of dice.
  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
def apply( func: Callable, *dice, again_depth: int = 1, again_end=None) -> icepool.Die: 
274def apply(func: Callable,
275          *dice,
276          again_depth: int = 1,
277          again_end=None) -> 'icepool.Die':
278    """Applies `func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...)` for all outcomes of the dice.
279
280    Example: `apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6)` is the same as d6 + d6.
281
282    `apply()` is flexible but not very efficient for more than a few dice.
283    Instead of using several arguments:
284
285    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each
286        outcome, one outcome at a time, try using
287        `icepool.Pool` and `icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator`.
288    * If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional `Die` at a
289        time, try using `reduce()` instead.
290    * If the order in which the dice are rolled is not important, you can use
291        `apply_sorted()`. This is less efficient than either of the above two,
292        but is still more efficient than `apply()`.
293
294    Args:
295        func: A function that takes one argument per input `Die` and returns an
296            argument to `Die()`.
297        *dice: Any number of dice. `func` will be called with all joint outcomes
298            of `dice`, with one argument per `Die`.
299            Non-dice will be left as-is.
300        again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
301        again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
302
303    Returns:
304        A `Die` constructed from the outputs of `func` and the product of the
305        quantities of the dice.
306    """
307    if not callable(func):
308        raise TypeError(
309            'The first argument must be callable. Did you forget to provide a function?'
310        )
311    if len(dice) == 0:
312        return icepool.Die([func()],
313                           again_depth=again_depth,
314                           again_end=again_end)
315    final_outcomes = []
316    final_quantities = []
317    for outcomes, final_quantity in iter_product_args(*dice):
318        final_outcome = func(*outcomes)
319        if final_outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
320            final_outcomes.append(final_outcome)
321            final_quantities.append(final_quantity)
322
323    return icepool.Die(final_outcomes,
324                       final_quantities,
325                       again_depth=again_depth,
326                       again_end=again_end)

Applies func(outcome_of_die_0, outcome_of_die_1, ...) for all outcomes of the dice.

Example: apply(lambda a, b: a + b, d6, d6) is the same as d6 + d6.

apply() is flexible but not very efficient for more than a few dice. Instead of using several arguments:

  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering how many dice rolled each outcome, one outcome at a time, try using icepool.Pool and icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.
  • If the problem is easy to solve by considering one additional Die at a time, try using reduce() instead.
  • If the order in which the dice are rolled is not important, you can use apply_sorted(). This is less efficient than either of the above two, but is still more efficient than apply().
Arguments:
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input Die and returns an argument to Die().
  • *dice: Any number of dice. func will be called with all joint outcomes of dice, with one argument per Die. Non-dice will be left as-is.
  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
Returns:

A Die constructed from the outputs of func and the product of the quantities of the dice.

336            cls,

341        """Applies `func(lowest_outcome, next_lowest_outcome...)` for all sorted joint outcomes of the dice.
342
343        Treat this as an ordinary function, not a constructor.
344
345        `apply_sorted()` is more efficient than `apply()` but still not very
346        efficient. Use `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instead if at all possible.
347
348        You can use `apply_sorted[]` to only see outcomes at particular sorted indexes.
349        For example, `apply_sorted[-2:](func, *dice)` would give the two highest
350        outcomes to `func()`. This is more efficient than selecting outcomes inside
351        `func`.
352
353        Args:
354            func: A function that takes one argument per input `Die` and returns an
355                argument to `Die()`.
356            *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice).
357                `func` will be called with all sorted joint outcomes of `dice`,
358                with one argument per die. All outcomes must be totally orderable.
359            again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
360            again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
361
362        Returns:
363            A `Die` constructed from the outputs of `func` and the weight of rolling
364            the corresponding sorted outcomes.
365        """
366        if not callable(func):
367            raise TypeError(
368                'The first argument must be callable. Did you forget to provide a function?'
369            )
370        pool = icepool.Pool(dice)
371        return pool.expand().sub(func,
372                                 star=1,
373                                 again_depth=again_depth,
374                                 again_end=again_end)

Applies func(lowest_outcome, next_lowest_outcome...) for all sorted joint outcomes of the dice.

Treat this as an ordinary function, not a constructor.

apply_sorted() is more efficient than apply() but still not very efficient. Use OutcomeCountEvaluator instead if at all possible.

You can use apply_sorted[] to only see outcomes at particular sorted indexes. For example, apply_sorted[-2:](func, *dice) would give the two highest outcomes to func(). This is more efficient than selecting outcomes inside func.

Arguments:
  • func: A function that takes one argument per input Die and returns an argument to Die().
  • *dice: Any number of dice (or objects convertible to dice). func will be called with all sorted joint outcomes of dice, with one argument per die. All outcomes must be totally orderable.
  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
Returns:

A Die constructed from the outputs of func and the weight of rolling the corresponding sorted outcomes.

Reroll = <SpecialValue.Reroll: 'Reroll'>

Indicates that an outcome should be rerolled (with unlimited depth).

This can be used in place of outcomes in many places. See individual function and method descriptions for details.

This effectively removes the outcome from the probability space, along with its contribution to the denominator.

This can be used for conditional probability by removing all outcomes not consistent with the given observations.

Operation in specific cases:

  • When used with Again, only that stage is rerolled, not the entire Again tree.
  • To reroll with limited depth, use Die.reroll(), or Again() with no modification.
  • When used with OutcomeCountEvaluator, the entire evaluation is rerolled.
Unlimited
class OutcomeCountGenerator(abc.ABC): 
 19class OutcomeCountGenerator(ABC):
 20    """Abstract base class for incrementally generating `(outcome, counts, weight)`s.
 21
 22    These include dice pools (`Pool`) and card deals (`Deal`). Most likely you
 23    will be using one of these two rather than writing your own subclass of
 24    `OutcomeCountGenerator`.
 25
 26    These generators can be evaluated by an `OutcomeCountEvaluator`, which you
 27    *are* likely to write your own concrete subclass of.
 28    """
 29
 30    @abstractmethod
 31    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
 32        """The set of outcomes, in sorted order."""
 33
 34    @abstractmethod
 35    def counts_len(self) -> int:
 36        """The number of counts generated. Must be constant."""
 37
 38    @abstractmethod
 39    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
 40        """`True` iff the generator is capable of producing an overall outcome.
 41
 42        For example, a dice `Pool` will return `False` if it contains any dice
 43        with no outcomes.
 44        """
 45
 46    @abstractmethod
 47    def _generate_min(self, min_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
 48        """Pops the min outcome from this generator if it matches the argument.
 49
 50        Yields:
 51            * A generator with the min outcome popped.
 52            * A tuple of counts for the min outcome.
 53            * The weight for this many of the min outcome appearing.
 54
 55            If the argument does not match the min outcome, or this generator
 56            has no outcomes, only a single tuple is yielded:
 57
 58            * `self`
 59            * A tuple of zeros.
 60            * weight = 1.
 61        """
 62
 63    @abstractmethod
 64    def _generate_max(self, max_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
 65        """Pops the max outcome from this generator if it matches the argument.
 66
 67        Yields:
 68            * A generator with the min outcome popped.
 69            * A tuple of counts for the min outcome.
 70            * The weight for this many of the min outcome appearing.
 71
 72            If the argument does not match the min outcome, or this generator
 73            has no outcomes, only a single tuple is yielded:
 74
 75            * `self`
 76            * A tuple of zeros.
 77            * weight = 1.
 78        """
 79
 80    @abstractmethod
 81    def _estimate_order_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
 82        """Estimates the cost of popping from the min and max sides during an evaluation.
 83
 84        Returns:
 85            pop_min_cost: A positive `int`.
 86            pop_max_cost: A positive `int`.
 87        """
 88
 89    @abstractmethod
 90    def denominator(self) -> int:
 91        """The total weight of all paths through this generator."""
 92
 93    @abstractmethod
 94    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
 95        """All `OutcomeCountGenerator`s must implement equality."""
 96
 97    @abstractmethod
 98    def __hash__(self) -> int:
 99        """All `OutcomeCountGenerator`s must be hashable."""
100
101    def evaluate(self,
102                 evaluator_or_func: 'icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator' | Callable,
103                 /) -> 'icepool.Die':
104        """Evaluates this generator using the given `OutcomeCountEvaluator` or function.
105
106        Note that each `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instance carries its own cache;
107        if you plan to use an evaluation multiple times,
108        you may want to explicitly create an `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instance
109        rather than passing a function to this method directly.
110
111        Args:
112            func: This can be an `OutcomeCountEvaluator`, in which case it evaluates
113                the generator directly.
114                Or it can be a `OutcomeCountEvaluator.next_state()`-like
115                function, taking in `state, outcome, *counts` and returning the
116                next state. In this case a temporary `WrapFuncEvaluator`
117                is constructed and used to evaluate this generator.
118        """
119        if not isinstance(evaluator_or_func, icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator):
120            evaluator_or_func = icepool.WrapFuncEvaluator(evaluator_or_func)
121        return evaluator_or_func.evaluate(self)
122
123    def min_outcome(self):
124        return self.outcomes()[0]
125
126    def max_outcome(self):
127        return self.outcomes()[-1]
128
129    # Built-in evaluators.
130
131    def expand(self, unique=False) -> 'icepool.Die':
132        """All possible (unordered) tuples of outcomes.
133
134        This is expensive and not recommended unless there are few possibilities.
135
136        Args:
137            unique: If set, at most one of each outcome will be produced.
138        """
139        if unique:
140            return icepool.ExpandEvaluator(unique=True).evaluate(self)
141        else:
142            return icepool.expand_evaluator.evaluate(self)
143
144    def sum(
145        self,
146        *,
147        sub: Callable[[Hashable], Hashable] | Mapping[Hashable, Hashable] |
148        None = None
149    ) -> 'icepool.Die':
150        """The sum of the outcomes.
151
152        Args:
153            sub: If provided, the outcomes will be substituted according to
154                this before summing.
155        """
156        if sub is not None:
157            return icepool.SumEvaluator(sub=sub)(self)
158        else:
159            return icepool.sum_evaluator(self)
160
161    def count(self, target, /) -> 'icepool.Die':
162        """The number of outcomes that are == the target.
163
164        If no target is provided, all outcomes will be counted.
165        """
166        return icepool.CountInEvaluator({target}).evaluate(self)
167
168    def count_in(self, target: Container, /) -> 'icepool.Die':
169        """The number of outcomes that are in the target."""
170        return icepool.CountInEvaluator(target).evaluate(self)
171
172    def count_unique(self) -> 'icepool.Die':
173        """The number of outcomes with count greater than zero."""
174        return icepool.count_unique_evaluator.evaluate(self)
175
176    def contains_subset(self,
177                        targets: Collection | Mapping[Any, int],
178                        /,
179                        *,
180                        wilds: Collection = ()) -> 'icepool.Die':
181        """Whether the outcomes contain all of the targets.
182
183        The targets may contain duplicate elements.
184
185        Args:
186            targets: Either a collection of outcomes, counting once per appearance.
187                Or a mapping from outcomes to target counts.
188            wilds: A collection of outcomes that will be treated as wilds.
189        """
190        return icepool.ContainsSubsetEvaluator(targets,
191                                               wilds=wilds).evaluate(self)
192
193    def intersection_size(self,
194                          targets: Collection | Mapping[Any, int],
195                          /,
196                          *,
197                          wilds: Collection = ()) -> 'icepool.Die':
198        """The size of the intersection of the outcomes and the targets.
199
200        The targets may contain duplicate elements.
201
202        E.g. a roll of 1, 2, 2 and a target of 1, 1, 2, 3 would result in 2.
203
204        Args:
205            targets: Either a collection of outcomes, counting once per appearance.
206                Or a mapping from outcomes to target counts.
207            wilds: A collection of outcomes that will be treated as wilds.
208        """
209        return icepool.IntersectionSizeEvaluator(targets,
210                                                 wilds=wilds).evaluate(self)
211
212    def best_matching_set(self) -> 'icepool.Die':
213        """The best matching set among the outcomes.
214
215        Returns:
216            A `Die` with outcomes (set_size, outcome).
217            The greatest single such set is returned.
218        """
219        return icepool.best_matching_set_evaluator.evaluate(self)
220
221    def best_straight(self) -> 'icepool.Die':
222        """The best straight among the outcomes.
223
224        Outcomes must be `int`s.
225
226        Returns:
227            A `Die` with outcomes (straight_length, outcome).
228            The greatest single such straight is returned.
229        """
230        return icepool.best_straight_evaluator.evaluate(self)
231
232    # Sampling.
233
234    def sample(self) -> tuple[tuple, ...]:
235        """EXPERIMENTAL: A single random sample from this generator.
236
237        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
238        secure.
239
240        Returns:
241            A sorted tuple of outcomes for each output of this generator.
242        """
243        if not self.outcomes():
244            raise ValueError('Cannot sample from an empty set of outcomes.')
245
246        min_cost, max_cost = self._estimate_order_costs()
247
248        if min_cost < max_cost:
249            outcome = self.min_outcome()
250            generated = tuple(self._generate_min(outcome))
251        else:
252            outcome = self.max_outcome()
253            generated = tuple(self._generate_max(outcome))
254
255        cumulative_weights = tuple(
256            itertools.accumulate(g.denominator() * w for g, _, w in generated))
257        denominator = cumulative_weights[-1]
258        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
259        r = random.randrange(denominator)
260        index = bisect.bisect_right(cumulative_weights, r)
261        popped_generator, counts, _ = generated[index]
262        head = tuple((outcome,) * count for count in counts)
263        if popped_generator.outcomes():
264            tail = popped_generator.sample()
265            return tuple(tuple(sorted(h + t)) for h, t, in zip(head, tail))
266        else:
267            return head

Abstract base class for incrementally generating (outcome, counts, weight)s.

These include dice pools (Pool) and card deals (Deal). Most likely you will be using one of these two rather than writing your own subclass of OutcomeCountGenerator.

These generators can be evaluated by an OutcomeCountEvaluator, which you are likely to write your own concrete subclass of.

36        """The number of counts generated. Must be constant."""

The number of counts generated. Must be constant.

@abstractmethod
def denominator(self) -> int:

The total weight of all paths through this generator.

def evaluate( self, evaluator_or_func: Union[icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator, Callable], /) -> icepool.Die: 
101    def evaluate(self,
102                 evaluator_or_func: 'icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator' | Callable,
103                 /) -> 'icepool.Die':
104        """Evaluates this generator using the given `OutcomeCountEvaluator` or function.
105
106        Note that each `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instance carries its own cache;
107        if you plan to use an evaluation multiple times,
108        you may want to explicitly create an `OutcomeCountEvaluator` instance
109        rather than passing a function to this method directly.
110
111        Args:
112            func: This can be an `OutcomeCountEvaluator`, in which case it evaluates
113                the generator directly.
114                Or it can be a `OutcomeCountEvaluator.next_state()`-like
115                function, taking in `state, outcome, *counts` and returning the
116                next state. In this case a temporary `WrapFuncEvaluator`
117                is constructed and used to evaluate this generator.
118        """
119        if not isinstance(evaluator_or_func, icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator):
120            evaluator_or_func = icepool.WrapFuncEvaluator(evaluator_or_func)
121        return evaluator_or_func.evaluate(self)

235        """EXPERIMENTAL: A single random sample from this generator.
236
237        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
238        secure.

247
