class Pool(icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator): 
 40class Pool(OutcomeCountGenerator):
 41    """Represents a set of sorted/unordered dice, only distinguished by the outcomes they roll.
 42
 43    This should be used in conjunction with `OutcomeCountEvaluator` to generate a result.
 44    """
 45
 46    _sorted_roll_counts: tuple[int, ...]
 47    _dice: tuple[tuple['icepool.Die', int]]
 48
 49    def __new__(cls,
 50                dice: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 51                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1) -> 'Pool':
 52        """Public constructor for a pool.
 53
 54        Evaulation is most efficient when the dice are the same or same-side
 55        truncations of each other. For example, d4, d6, d8, d10, d12 are all
 56        same-side truncations of d12.
 57
 58        Args:
 59            dice: The dice to put in the `Pool`. This can be one of the following:
 60
 61                * A sequence of dice.
 62                * A mapping of dice and how many of that `Die` to put in the `Pool`.
 63
 64                All outcomes within a `Pool` must be totally orderable.
 65            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `dice` will
 66                be put into the pool.
 67                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 68                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 69                `outcomes`.
 70
 71        Raises:
 72            ValueError: If a bare `Deck` or `Die` argument is provided.
 73                A `Pool` of a single `Die` should constructed as `Pool([die])`.
 74        """
 75        if isinstance(dice, Pool):
 76            if times == 1:
 77                return dice
 78            else:
 79                dice = dice._dice
 80
 81        if isinstance(dice, (icepool.Deck, icepool.Deal)):
 82            raise ValueError(
 83                f'A Pool cannot be constructed with a {type(dice).__name__} argument.'
 84            )
 85
 86        if isinstance(dice, icepool.Die):
 87            raise ValueError(
 88                'A Pool cannot be constructed with a Die argument. '
 89                'Use Pool([die]) or die.pool() to construct a pool of a single die.'
 90            )
 91
 92        dice, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(dice, times)
 93        dice = tuple(icepool.implicit_convert_to_die(die) for die in dice)
 94
 95        dice_counts: MutableMapping['icepool.Die', int] = defaultdict(int)
 96        for die, qty in zip(dice, times):
 97            dice_counts[die] += qty
 98        sorted_roll_counts = (1,) * sum(times)
 99        return cls._new_pool_from_mapping(dice_counts, sorted_roll_counts)
100
101    @classmethod
102    def _new_pool_from_mapping(cls, dice_counts: Mapping['icepool.Die', int],
103                               sorted_roll_counts: Sequence[int]) -> 'Pool':
104        """Creates a new pool.
105
106        Args:
107            dice_counts: A map from dice to rolls.
108            sorted_roll_counts: A tuple with length equal to the number of dice.
109        """
110        dice = tuple(
111            sorted(dice_counts.items(), key=lambda kv: kv[0].key_tuple()))
112        return new_pool_cached(
113            cls,  # type: ignore
114            dice,
115            sorted_roll_counts)
116
117    @classmethod
118    def _new_pool_from_tuple(cls, dice: tuple[tuple['icepool.Die', int]],
119                             sorted_roll_counts: tuple[int, ...]) -> 'Pool':
120        """Creates a new pool.
121
122        Args:
123            dice: A sorted tuple of (dice, count).
124            sorted_roll_counts: A tuple with length equal to the number of dice.
125        """
126        return new_pool_cached(
127            cls,  # type: ignore
128            dice,
129            sorted_roll_counts)
130
131    @cached_property
132    def _size(self) -> int:
133        return sum(count for _, count in self._dice)
134
135    def size(self) -> int:
136        """The number of dice in this pool, counting multiples of the same `Die`."""
137        return self._size
138
139    def _is_resolvable(self) -> bool:
140        return all(not die.is_empty() for die, _ in self._dice)
141
142    @cached_property
143    def _denominator(self) -> int:
144        return math.prod(die.denominator()**count for die, count in self._dice)
145
146    def denominator(self) -> int:
147        return self._denominator
148
149    @cached_property
150    def _dice_tuple(self) -> tuple['icepool.Die', ...]:
151        return sum(((die,) * count for die, count in self._dice), start=())
152
153    @cached_property
154    def _unique_dice(self) -> Collection['icepool.Die']:
155        return set(die for die, _ in self._dice)
156
157    def unique_dice(self) -> Collection['icepool.Die']:
158        """The collection of unique dice in this pool."""
159        return self._unique_dice
160
161    @cached_property
162    def _outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
163        outcome_set = set(
164            itertools.chain.from_iterable(
165                die.outcomes() for die in self.unique_dice()))
166        return tuple(sorted(outcome_set))
167
168    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence:
169        """The union of outcomes among all dice in this pool."""
170        return self._outcomes
171
172    def counts_len(self) -> int:
173        return 1
174
175    def _estimate_order_costs(self) -> tuple[int, int]:
176        """Estimates the cost of popping from the min and max sides.
177
178        Returns:
179            pop_min_cost
180            pop_max_cost
181        """
182        return icepool.pool_cost.estimate_costs(self)
183
184    def sorted_roll_counts(self) -> tuple[int, ...]:
185        """The tuple indicating which dice in the pool will be counted.
186
187        The tuple has one element per `Die` in the pool, from lowest roll to
188        highest roll. The `Die` in the corresponding sorted position will be
189        counted that many times.
190        """
191        return self._sorted_roll_counts
192
193    def set_sorted_roll_counts(self,
194                               sorted_roll_counts: int | slice | Sequence[int]):
195        """A `Pool` with the selected dice counted after rolling and sorting.
196
197        Use `pool[sorted_roll_counts]` for the same effect as this method.
198
199        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
200        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
201
202        This is always an absolute selection on all `size` dice,
203        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
204        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
205
206        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
207
208        * `pool[3:5]`
209        * `pool[3:]`
210        * `pool[-2:]`
211        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
212        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
213
214        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
215
216        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
217        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
218
219        Args: One of the following:
220            * An `int`. This will count only the `Die` at the specified index
221                (once). In this case, the result will be a `Die`, not a `Pool`.
222            * A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
223            * A sequence of one `int` for each `Die`.
224                Each `Die` is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
225                negative times.
226
227                Up to one `...` (`Ellipsis`) may be used.
228                `...` will be replaced with a number of zero
229                counts depending on the size of the pool.
230                This number may be "negative" if more `int`s are provided than
231                the size of the `Pool`. Specifically:
232
233                * If `sorted_roll_counts` is shorter than `size`, `...`
234                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
235                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
236                * If `sorted_roll_counts` has length equal to `size`, `...` has no effect.
237                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
238                * If `sorted_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and `...` is on one side,
239                    elements will be dropped from `sorted_roll_counts` on the side with `...`.
240                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
241                * If `sorted_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and `...`
242                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
243                    one-sided `...`.
244                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
245                    On a `Pool` consisting of a single `Die` this would have
246                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
247
248        Raises:
249            ValueError: If more than one `...` is used.
250        """
251        convert_to_die = isinstance(sorted_roll_counts, int)
252        sorted_roll_counts = sorted_roll_counts_tuple(self.size(),
253                                                      sorted_roll_counts)
254        if len(sorted_roll_counts) != self.size():
255            if len(self._dice) != 1:
256                raise ValueError(
257                    'Cannot change the size of a pool unless it has exactly one type of die.'
258                )
259            dice = Counts([(self._dice[0][0], len(sorted_roll_counts))])
260            result = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(dice, sorted_roll_counts)
261        else:
262            result = Pool._new_pool_from_tuple(self._dice, sorted_roll_counts)
263        if convert_to_die:
264            return result.evaluate(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
265                                   if count else state)
266        else:
267            return result
268
269    __getitem__ = set_sorted_roll_counts
270
271    @cached_property
272    def _min_outcome(self):
273        return min(die.min_outcome() for die in self.unique_dice())
274
275    def min_outcome(self):
276        """The min outcome among all dice in this pool."""
277        return self._min_outcome
278
279    @cached_property
280    def _max_outcome(self):
281        return max(die.max_outcome() for die in self.unique_dice())
282
283    def max_outcome(self):
284        """The max outcome among all dice in this pool."""
285        return self._max_outcome
286
287    def _generate_min(self, min_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
288        """Pops the given outcome from this pool, if it is the min outcome.
289
290        Yields:
291            popped_pool: The pool after the min outcome is popped.
292            net_count: The number of dice that rolled the min outcome, after
293                accounting for sorted_roll_counts.
294            net_weight: The weight of this incremental result.
295        """
296        if not self.outcomes():
297            yield self, (0,), 1
298            return
299        generators = [
300            iter_die_pop_min(die, die_count, min_outcome)
301            for die, die_count in self._dice
302        ]
303        skip_weight = None
304        for pop in itertools.product(*generators):
305            total_hits = 0
306            result_weight = 1
307            next_dice_counts: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
308            for popped_die, misses, hits, weight in pop:
309                if not popped_die.is_empty():
310                    next_dice_counts[popped_die] += misses
311                total_hits += hits
312                result_weight *= weight
313            if total_hits == 0:
314                result_count = 0
315                popped_sorted_roll_counts = self.sorted_roll_counts()
316            else:
317                result_count = sum(self.sorted_roll_counts()[:total_hits])
318                popped_sorted_roll_counts = self.sorted_roll_counts(
319                )[total_hits:]
320            popped_pool = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(
321                next_dice_counts, popped_sorted_roll_counts)
322            if not any(popped_sorted_roll_counts):
323                # Dump all dice in exchange for the denominator.
324                skip_weight = (skip_weight or
325                               0) + result_weight * popped_pool.denominator()
326                continue
327
328            yield popped_pool, (result_count,), result_weight
329
330        if skip_weight is not None:
331            yield Pool([]), (sum(self.sorted_roll_counts()),), skip_weight
332
333    def _generate_max(self, max_outcome) -> NextOutcomeCountGenerator:
334        """Pops the given outcome from this pool, if it is the max outcome.
335
336        Yields:
337            popped_pool: The pool after the max outcome is popped.
338            net_count: The number of dice that rolled the max outcome, after
339                accounting for sorted_roll_counts.
340            net_weight: The weight of this incremental result.
341        """
342        if not self.outcomes():
343            yield self, (0,), 1
344            return
345        generators = [
346            iter_die_pop_max(die, die_count, max_outcome)
347            for die, die_count in self._dice
348        ]
349        skip_weight = None
350        for pop in itertools.product(*generators):
351            total_hits = 0
352            result_weight = 1
353            next_dice_counts: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
354            for popped_die, misses, hits, weight in pop:
355                if not popped_die.is_empty():
356                    next_dice_counts[popped_die] += misses
357                total_hits += hits
358                result_weight *= weight
359            if total_hits == 0:
360                result_count = 0
361                popped_sorted_roll_counts = self.sorted_roll_counts()
362            else:
363                result_count = sum(self.sorted_roll_counts()[-total_hits:])
364                popped_sorted_roll_counts = self.sorted_roll_counts(
365                )[:-total_hits]
366            popped_pool = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(
367                next_dice_counts, popped_sorted_roll_counts)
368            if not any(popped_sorted_roll_counts):
369                # Dump all dice in exchange for the denominator.
370                skip_weight = (skip_weight or
371                               0) + result_weight * popped_pool.denominator()
372                continue
373
374            yield popped_pool, (result_count,), result_weight
375
376        if skip_weight is not None:
377            yield Pool([]), (sum(self.sorted_roll_counts()),), skip_weight
378
379    def lowest(self, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'icepool.Die':
380        """The lowest outcome or sum of the lowest outcomes in the pool.
381
382        The args override any `sorted_roll_counts` of this pool.
383
384        Args:
385            keep: The number of lowest dice will be summed.
386            drop: This number of lowest dice will be dropped before keeping
387                dice to be summed.
388        """
389        if keep < 0:
390            raise ValueError(f'keep={keep} cannot be negative.')
391        if drop < 0:
392            raise ValueError(f'drop={drop} cannot be negative.')
393
394        start = min(drop, self.size())
395        stop = min(keep + drop, self.size())
396        return self[start:stop].sum()  # type: ignore
397
398    def highest(self, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'icepool.Die':
399        """The highest outcome or sum of the highest outcomes in the pool.
400
401        The args override any `sorted_roll_counts` of this pool.
402
403        Args:
404            keep: The number of highest dice will be summed.
405            drop: This number of highest dice will be dropped before keeping
406                dice to be summed.
407        """
408        if keep < 0:
409            raise ValueError(f'keep={keep} cannot be negative.')
410        if drop < 0:
411            raise ValueError(f'drop={drop} cannot be negative.')
412
413        start = self.size() - min(keep + drop, self.size())
414        stop = self.size() - min(drop, self.size())
415        return self[start:stop].sum()  # type: ignore
416
417    def __str__(self) -> str:
418        return (
419            f'Pool of {self.size()} dice with sorted_roll_counts={self.sorted_roll_counts()}\n'
420            + ''.join(f'  {repr(die)}\n' for die in self._dice_tuple))
421
422    @cached_property
423    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
424        return Pool, self._dice, self._sorted_roll_counts
425
426    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
427        if not isinstance(other, Pool):
428            return False
429        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
430
431    @cached_property
432    def _hash(self) -> int:
433        return hash(self._key_tuple)
434
435    def __hash__(self) -> int:
436        return self._hash

Represents a set of sorted/unordered dice, only distinguished by the outcomes they roll.

This should be used in conjunction with OutcomeCountEvaluator to generate a result.

Pool( dice: Union[Mapping[Any, int], Sequence], times: Union[Sequence[int], int] = 1) 
49    def __new__(cls,
50                dice: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
51                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1) -> 'Pool':
52        """Public constructor for a pool.
53
54        Evaulation is most efficient when the dice are the same or same-side
55        truncations of each other. For example, d4, d6, d8, d10, d12 are all
56        same-side truncations of d12.
57
58        Args:
59            dice: The dice to put in the `Pool`. This can be one of the following:
60
61                * A sequence of dice.
62                * A mapping of dice and how many of that `Die` to put in the `Pool`.
63
64                All outcomes within a `Pool` must be totally orderable.
65            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `dice` will
66                be put into the pool.
67                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
68                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
69                `outcomes`.
70
71        Raises:
72            ValueError: If a bare `Deck` or `Die` argument is provided.
73                A `Pool` of a single `Die` should constructed as `Pool([die])`.
74        """
75        if isinstance(dice, Pool):
76            if times == 1:
77                return dice
78            else:
79                dice = dice._dice
80
81        if isinstance(dice, (icepool.Deck, icepool.Deal)):
82            raise ValueError(
83                f'A Pool cannot be constructed with a {type(dice).__name__} argument.'
84            )
85
86        if isinstance(dice, icepool.Die):
87            raise ValueError(
88                'A Pool cannot be constructed with a Die argument. '
89                'Use Pool([die]) or die.pool() to construct a pool of a single die.'
90            )
91
92        dice, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(dice, times)
93        dice = tuple(icepool.implicit_convert_to_die(die) for die in dice)
94
95        dice_counts: MutableMapping['icepool.Die', int] = defaultdict(int)
96        for die, qty in zip(dice, times):
97            dice_counts[die] += qty
98        sorted_roll_counts = (1,) * sum(times)
99        return cls._new_pool_from_mapping(dice_counts, sorted_roll_counts)

Public constructor for a pool.

Evaulation is most efficient when the dice are the same or same-side truncations of each other. For example, d4, d6, d8, d10, d12 are all same-side truncations of d12.

def set_sorted_roll_counts(self, sorted_roll_counts: Union[int, slice, Sequence[int]]): 
193    def set_sorted_roll_counts(self,
194                               sorted_roll_counts: int | slice | Sequence[int]):
195        """A `Pool` with the selected dice counted after rolling and sorting.
196
197        Use `pool[sorted_roll_counts]` for the same effect as this method.
198
199        The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose,
200        regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.
201
202        This is always an absolute selection on all `size` dice,
203        not a relative selection on already-selected dice,
204        which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.
205
206        For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:
207
208        * `pool[3:5]`
209        * `pool[3:]`
210        * `pool[-2:]`
211        * `pool[..., 1, 1]`
212        * `pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]`
213
214        These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:
215
216        * `pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`
217        * `pool[-1, ..., 1]`
218
219        Args: One of the following:
220            * An `int`. This will count only the `Die` at the specified index
221                (once). In this case, the result will be a `Die`, not a `Pool`.
222            * A `slice`. The selected dice are counted once each.
223            * A sequence of one `int` for each `Die`.
224                Each `Die` is counted that many times, which could be multiple or
225                negative times.
226
227                Up to one `...` (`Ellipsis`) may be used.
228                `...` will be replaced with a number of zero
229                counts depending on the size of the pool.
230                This number may be "negative" if more `int`s are provided than
231                the size of the `Pool`. Specifically:
232
233                * If `sorted_roll_counts` is shorter than `size`, `...`
234                    acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
235                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
236                * If `sorted_roll_counts` has length equal to `size`, `...` has no effect.
237                    E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
238                * If `sorted_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and `...` is on one side,
239                    elements will be dropped from `sorted_roll_counts` on the side with `...`.
240                    E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
241                * If `sorted_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and `...`
242                    is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
243                    one-sided `...`.
244                    E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
245                    On a `Pool` consisting of a single `Die` this would have
246                    the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
247
248        Raises:
249            ValueError: If more than one `...` is used.
250        """
251        convert_to_die = isinstance(sorted_roll_counts, int)
252        sorted_roll_counts = sorted_roll_counts_tuple(self.size(),
253                                                      sorted_roll_counts)
254        if len(sorted_roll_counts) != self.size():
255            if len(self._dice) != 1:
256                raise ValueError(
257                    'Cannot change the size of a pool unless it has exactly one type of die.'
258                )
259            dice = Counts([(self._dice[0][0], len(sorted_roll_counts))])
260            result = Pool._new_pool_from_mapping(dice, sorted_roll_counts)
261        else:
262            result = Pool._new_pool_from_tuple(self._dice, sorted_roll_counts)
263        if convert_to_die:
264            return result.evaluate(lambda state, outcome, count: outcome
265                                   if count else state)
266        else:
267            return result

A Pool with the selected dice counted after rolling and sorting.

Use pool[sorted_roll_counts] for the same effect as this method.

The dice are sorted in ascending order for this purpose, regardless of which order the outcomes are evaluated in.

This is always an absolute selection on all size dice, not a relative selection on already-selected dice, which would be ambiguous in the presence of multiple or negative counts.

For example, here are some ways of selecting the two highest dice out of 5:

  • pool[3:5]
  • pool[3:]
  • pool[-2:]
  • pool[..., 1, 1]
  • pool[0, 0, 0, 1, 1]

These will count the highest as a positive and the lowest as a negative:

  • pool[-1, 0, 0, 0, 1]
  • pool[-1, ..., 1]

Args: One of the following: * An int. This will count only the Die at the specified index (once). In this case, the result will be a Die, not a Pool. * A slice. The selected dice are counted once each. * A sequence of one int for each Die. Each Die is counted that many times, which could be multiple or negative times.

    Up to one `...` (`Ellipsis`) may be used.
    `...` will be replaced with a number of zero
    counts depending on the size of the pool.
    This number may be "negative" if more `int`s are provided than
    the size of the `Pool`. Specifically:

    * If `sorted_roll_counts` is shorter than `size`, `...`
        acts as enough zero counts to make up the difference.
        E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on five dice would act as `pool[1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`.
    * If `sorted_roll_counts` has length equal to `size`, `...` has no effect.
        E.g. `pool[1, ..., 1]` on two dice would act as `pool[1, 1]`.
    * If `sorted_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and `...` is on one side,
        elements will be dropped from `sorted_roll_counts` on the side with `...`.
        E.g. `pool[..., 1, 2, 3]` on two dice would act as `pool[2, 3]`.
    * If `sorted_roll_counts` is longer than `size` and `...`
        is in the middle, the counts will be as the sum of two
        one-sided `...`.
        E.g. `pool[-1, ..., 1]` acts like `[-1, ...]` plus `[..., 1]`.
        On a `Pool` consisting of a single `Die` this would have
        the -1 and 1 cancel each other out.
Raises:
  • ValueError: If more than one ... is used.

class OutcomeCountEvaluator(abc.ABC): 
 27class OutcomeCountEvaluator(ABC):
 28    """An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more `OutcomeCountGenerator`s.
 29
 30    There is one abstract method to implement: `next_state()`.
 31    This should incrementally calculate the result given one outcome at a time
 32    along with how many of that outcome were produced.
 33
 34    An example sequence of calls, as far as `next_state()` is concerned, is:
 35
 36    1. `state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count_of_1s)`
 37    2. `state = next_state(state, 2, count_of_2s)`
 38    3. `state = next_state(state, 3, count_of_3s)`
 39    4. `state = next_state(state, 4, count_of_4s)`
 40    5. `state = next_state(state, 5, count_of_5s)`
 41    6. `state = next_state(state, 6, count_of_6s)`
 42    7. `outcome = final_outcome(state, *generators)`
 43
 44    A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.
 45
 46    It is not expected that subclasses of `OutcomeCountEvaluator`
 47    be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of generators.
 48    Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of generators,
 49    and often even only generators with a particular type of `Die`.
 50
 51    Instances cache all intermediate state distributions.
 52    You should therefore reuse instances when possible.
 53
 54    Instances should not be modified after construction
 55    in any way that affects the return values of these methods.
 56    Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.
 57    """
 58
 59    @abstractmethod
 60    def next_state(self, state: Hashable, outcome, /, *counts) -> Hashable:
 61        """State transition function.
 62
 63        This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome,
 64        and the number that outcome produced by each generator.
 65
 66        `evaluate()` will always call this using only positional arguments.
 67        Furthermore, there is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle
 68        an arbitrary number of counts. Thus, you are free to rename any of
 69        the parameters in a subclass, or to replace `*counts` with a fixed set
 70        of parameters.
 71
 72        Make sure to handle the base case where `state is None`.
 73
 74        States must be hashable. At current, they do not have to be orderable.
 75        However, this may change in the future, and if they are not totally
 76        orderable, you must override `final_outcome` to create totally orderable
 77        final outcomes.
 78
 79        The behavior of returning a `Die` from `next_state` is currently
 80        undefined.
 81
 82        Args:
 83            state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the
 84                current outcome. If this is the first outcome being considered,
 85                `state` will be `None`.
 86            outcome: The current outcome.
 87                `next_state` will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order;
 88                either ascending or descending depending on `order()`.
 89                If there are multiple generators, the set of outcomes is the
 90                union of the outcomes of the invididual generators. All outcomes
 91                with nonzero count will be seen. Outcomes with zero count
 92                may or may not be seen. If you need to enforce that certain
 93                outcomes are seen even if they have zero count, see
 94                `alignment()`.
 95            *counts: One value (usually an `int`) for each generator output
 96                indicating how many of the current outcome were produced.
 97                All outcomes with nonzero count are guaranteed to be seen.
 98                To guarantee that outcomes are seen even if they have zero
 99                count, override `alignment()`.
100
101        Returns:
102            A hashable object indicating the next state.
103            The special value `icepool.Reroll` can be used to immediately remove
104            the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.
105        """
106
107    def final_outcome(self, final_state: Hashable, /,
108                      *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Any:
109        """Optional function to generate a final outcome from a final state.
110
111        Tthere is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle
112        an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of
113        the parameters in a subclass, or to replace `*generators` with a fixed
114        set of parameters.
115
116        By default, the final outcome is equal to the final state.
117        Note that `None` is not a valid outcome for a `Die`,
118        and if there are no outcomes, the final state will be `None`.
119        Subclasses that want to handle this case should explicitly define what
120        happens.
121
122        Args:
123            final_state: A state after all outcomes have been processed.
124            *generators: One or more `OutcomeCountGenerator`s being evaluated.
125                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
126                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
127                parameters.
128
129        Returns:
130            A final outcome that will be used as part of constructing the result `Die`.
131            As usual for `Die()`, this could itself be a `Die` or `icepool.Reroll`.
132        """
133        return final_state
134
135    def order(self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Order:
136        """Optional function to determine the order in which `next_state()` will see outcomes.
137
138        There is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle
139        an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of
140        the parameters in a subclass, or to replace `*generators` with a fixed
141        set of parameters.
142
143        The default is ascending order. This works well with mixed standard dice,
144        and other dice that differ only by right-truncation.
145
146        Args:
147            *generators: One or more `OutcomeCountGenerator`s being evaluated.
148                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
149                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
150                parameters.
151
152        Returns:
153            * Order.Ascending (= 1)
154                if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in ascending order.
155            * Order.Descending (= -1)
156                if `next_state()` should always see the outcomes in descending order.
157            * Order.Any (= 0)
158                if the result of the evaluation is order-independent.
159        """
160        return Order.Ascending
161
162    def alignment(self,
163                  *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection:
164        """Optional method to specify an collection of outcomes that should always be given to `next_state()` even if they have zero count.
165
166        There is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle
167        an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of
168        the parameters in a subclass, or to replace `*generators` with a fixed
169        set of parameters.
170
171        The default implementation returns `()`; this means outcomes with zero
172        count may or may not be seen by `next_state`.
173
174        If you want the outcomes seen by `next_state` to be consecutive
175        `int`s, you can set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment`.
176        See `range_alignment()` below.
177        """
178        return ()
179
180    def range_alignment(
181            self,
182            *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Collection[int]:
183        """Example implementation of `alignment()` that produces consecutive `int` outcomes.
184
185        There is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle
186        an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of
187        the parameters in a subclass, or to replace `*generators` with a fixed
188        set of parameters.
189
190        Set `alignment = icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator.range_alignment` to use this.
191
192        Returns:
193            All `int`s from the min outcome to the max outcome among the generators,
194            inclusive.
195
196        Raises:
197            TypeError: if any generator has any non-`int` outcome.
198        """
199        if len(generators) == 0:
200            return ()
201
202        if any(
203                any(not isinstance(x, int)
204                    for x in generator.outcomes())
205                for generator in generators):
206            raise TypeError(
207                "range_alignment cannot be used with outcomes of type other than 'int'."
208            )
209
210        min_outcome = min(generator.min_outcome() for generator in generators)
211        max_outcome = max(generator.max_outcome() for generator in generators)
212        return range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1)
213
214    def final_kwargs(
215            self,
216            *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Mapping[str, Any]:
217        """Optional method to specify any extra keyword arguments to the final die constructor."""
218        return {}
219
220    @cached_property
221    def _cache(self) -> MutableMapping[Any, Mapping[Any, int]]:
222        """A cache of (order, generators) -> weight distribution over states. """
223        return {}
224
225    def evaluate(
226        self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator | Mapping[Any, int] |
227        Sequence
228    ) -> 'icepool.Die':
229        """Evaluates generator(s).
230
231        You can call the `OutcomeCountEvaluator` object directly for the same effect,
232        e.g. `sum_evaluator(generator)` is an alias for `sum_evaluator.evaluate(generator)`.
233
234        Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of generators.
235        The union of the outcomes of the generator(s) must be totally orderable.
236
237        Args:
238            *generators: Each element may be one of the following:
239                * A `OutcomeCountGenerator`.
240                * A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
241                * A sequence of arguments to create a `Pool`.
242
243        Returns:
244            A `Die` representing the distribution of the final score.
245        """
246
247        # Convert non-`Pool` arguments to `Pool`.
248        converted_generators = tuple(
249            generator if isinstance(generator, icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator
250                                   ) else icepool.Pool(generator)
251            for generator in generators)
252
253        if not all(generator._is_resolvable()
254                   for generator in converted_generators):
255            return icepool.Die([])
256
257        algorithm, order = self._select_algorithm(*converted_generators)
258
259        # We use a separate class to guarantee all outcomes are visited.
260        alignment = Alignment(self.alignment(*converted_generators))
261
262        dist = algorithm(order, alignment, tuple(converted_generators))
263
264        final_outcomes = []
265        final_weights = []
266        for state, weight in dist.items():
267            outcome = self.final_outcome(state, *converted_generators)
268            if outcome is None:
269                raise TypeError(
270                    "None is not a valid final outcome. "
271                    "This may have resulted from supplying an empty generator to OutcomeCountEvaluator. "
272                    "If so, refrain from using empty generators, or override OutcomeCountEvaluator.final_outcome() to handle this case."
273                )
274            if outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
275                final_outcomes.append(outcome)
276                final_weights.append(weight)
277
278        return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_weights,
279                           **self.final_kwargs(*converted_generators))
280
281    __call__ = evaluate
282
283    def _select_algorithm(
284            self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator
285    ) -> tuple[Callable, Order]:
286        """Selects an algorithm and iteration order.
287
288        Returns:
289            * The algorithm to use (`_eval_internal*`).
290            * The order in which `next_state()` sees outcomes.
291                1 for ascending and -1 for descending.
292        """
293        eval_order = self.order(*generators)
294
295        pop_min_costs, pop_max_costs = zip(
296            *(generator._estimate_order_costs() for generator in generators))
297
298        pop_min_cost = math.prod(pop_min_costs)
299        pop_max_cost = math.prod(pop_max_costs)
300
301        # No preferred order case: go directly with cost.
302        if eval_order == Order.Any:
303            if pop_max_cost <= pop_min_cost:
304                return self._eval_internal, Order.Ascending
305            else:
306                return self._eval_internal, Order.Descending
307
308        # Preferred order case.
309        # Go with the preferred order unless there is a "significant"
310        # cost factor.
311
312        if PREFERRED_ORDER_COST_FACTOR * pop_max_cost < pop_min_cost:
313            cost_order = Order.Ascending
314        elif PREFERRED_ORDER_COST_FACTOR * pop_min_cost < pop_max_cost:
315            cost_order = Order.Descending
316        else:
317            cost_order = Order.Any
318
319        if cost_order == Order.Any or eval_order == cost_order:
320            # Use the preferred algorithm.
321            return self._eval_internal, eval_order
322        else:
323            # Use the less-preferred algorithm.
324            return self._eval_internal_iterative, eval_order
325
326    def _eval_internal(
327        self, order: int, alignment: Alignment,
328        generators: tuple[icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator,
329                          ...]) -> Mapping[Any, int]:
330        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the more-preferred order,
331        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from wide to narrow.
332
333        All intermediate return values are cached in the instance.
334
335        Arguments:
336            order: The order in which to send outcomes to `next_state()`.
337            alignment: As `alignment()`. Elements will be popped off this
338                during recursion.
339            generators: One or more `OutcomeCountGenerators`s to evaluate. Elements
340                will be popped off this during recursion.
341
342        Returns:
343            A dict `{ state : weight }` describing the probability distribution
344                over states.
345        """
346        cache_key = (order, alignment, generators)
347        if cache_key in self._cache:
348            return self._cache[cache_key]
349
350        result: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
351
352        if all(not generator.outcomes()
353               for generator in generators) and not alignment.outcomes():
354            result = {None: 1}
355        else:
356            outcome, prev_alignment, iterators = OutcomeCountEvaluator._pop_generators(
357                order, alignment, generators)
358            for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
359                prev_generators, counts, weights = zip(*p)
360                counts = tuple(itertools.chain.from_iterable(counts))
361                prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
362                prev = self._eval_internal(order, prev_alignment,
363                                           prev_generators)
364                for prev_state, prev_weight in prev.items():
365                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
366                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
367                        result[state] += prev_weight * prod_weight
368
369        self._cache[cache_key] = result
370        return result
371
372    def _eval_internal_iterative(
373        self, order: int, alignment: Alignment,
374        generators: tuple[icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator,
375                          ...]) -> Mapping[Any, int]:
376        """Internal algorithm for iterating in the less-preferred order,
377        i.e. giving outcomes to `next_state()` from narrow to wide.
378
379        This algorithm does not perform persistent memoization.
380        """
381        if all(not generator.outcomes()
382               for generator in generators) and not alignment.outcomes():
383            return {None: 1}
384        dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
385        dist[None, alignment, generators] = 1
386        final_dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
387        while dist:
388            next_dist: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
389            for (prev_state, prev_alignment,
390                 prev_generators), weight in dist.items():
391                # The order flip here is the only purpose of this algorithm.
392                outcome, alignment, iterators = OutcomeCountEvaluator._pop_generators(
393                    -order, prev_alignment, prev_generators)
394                for p in itertools.product(*iterators):
395                    generators, counts, weights = zip(*p)
396                    counts = tuple(itertools.chain.from_iterable(counts))
397                    prod_weight = math.prod(weights)
398                    state = self.next_state(prev_state, outcome, *counts)
399                    if state is not icepool.Reroll:
400                        if all(not generator.outcomes()
401                               for generator in generators):
402                            final_dist[state] += weight * prod_weight
403                        else:
404                            next_dist[state, alignment,
405                                      generators] += weight * prod_weight
406            dist = next_dist
407        return final_dist
408
409    @staticmethod
410    def _pop_generators(
411        side: int, alignment: Alignment,
412        generators: tuple[icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator, ...]
413    ) -> tuple[Any, Alignment, tuple['icepool.NextOutcomeCountGenerator', ...]]:
414        """Pops a single outcome from the generators.
415
416        Returns:
417            * The popped outcome.
418            * The remaining alignment.
419            * A tuple of iterators over the resulting generators, counts, and weights.
420        """
421        alignment_and_generators = (alignment,) + generators
422        if side >= 0:
423            outcome = max(generator.max_outcome()
424                          for generator in alignment_and_generators
425                          if generator.outcomes())
426
427            next_alignment, _, _ = next(alignment._generate_max(outcome))
428
429            return outcome, next_alignment, tuple(
430                generator._generate_max(outcome) for generator in generators)
431        else:
432            outcome = min(generator.min_outcome()
433                          for generator in alignment_and_generators
434                          if generator.outcomes())
435
436            next_alignment, _, _ = next(alignment._generate_min(outcome))
437
438            return outcome, next_alignment, tuple(
439                generator._generate_min(outcome) for generator in generators)
440
441    def sample(self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator |
442               Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence):
443        """EXPERIMENTAL: Samples one result from the generator(s) and evaluates the result."""
444        # Convert non-`Pool` arguments to `Pool`.
445        converted_generators = tuple(
446            generator if isinstance(generator, icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator
447                                   ) else icepool.Pool(generator)
448            for generator in generators)
449
450        result = self.evaluate(*itertools.chain.from_iterable(
451            generator.sample() for generator in converted_generators))
452
453        if not result.is_empty():
454            return result.outcomes()[0]
455        else:
456            return result

An abstract, immutable, callable class for evaulating one or more OutcomeCountGenerators.

There is one abstract method to implement: next_state(). This should incrementally calculate the result given one outcome at a time along with how many of that outcome were produced.

An example sequence of calls, as far as next_state() is concerned, is:

  1. state = next_state(state=None, outcome=1, count_of_1s)
  2. state = next_state(state, 2, count_of_2s)
  3. state = next_state(state, 3, count_of_3s)
  4. state = next_state(state, 4, count_of_4s)
  5. state = next_state(state, 5, count_of_5s)
  6. state = next_state(state, 6, count_of_6s)
  7. outcome = final_outcome(state, *generators)

A few other methods can optionally be overridden to further customize behavior.

It is not expected that subclasses of OutcomeCountEvaluator be able to handle arbitrary types or numbers of generators. Indeed, most are expected to handle only a fixed number of generators, and often even only generators with a particular type of Die.

Instances cache all intermediate state distributions. You should therefore reuse instances when possible.

Instances should not be modified after construction in any way that affects the return values of these methods. Otherwise, values in the cache may be incorrect.

@abstractmethod
def next_state(self, state: Hashable, outcome, /, *counts) -> Hashable: 
 59    @abstractmethod
 60    def next_state(self, state: Hashable, outcome, /, *counts) -> Hashable:
 61        """State transition function.
 62
 63        This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome,
 64        and the number that outcome produced by each generator.
 65
 66        `evaluate()` will always call this using only positional arguments.
 67        Furthermore, there is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle
 68        an arbitrary number of counts. Thus, you are free to rename any of
 69        the parameters in a subclass, or to replace `*counts` with a fixed set
 70        of parameters.
 71
 72        Make sure to handle the base case where `state is None`.
 73
 74        States must be hashable. At current, they do not have to be orderable.
 75        However, this may change in the future, and if they are not totally
 76        orderable, you must override `final_outcome` to create totally orderable
 77        final outcomes.
 78
 79        The behavior of returning a `Die` from `next_state` is currently
 80        undefined.
 81
 82        Args:
 83            state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the
 84                current outcome. If this is the first outcome being considered,
 85                `state` will be `None`.
 86            outcome: The current outcome.
 87                `next_state` will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order;
 88                either ascending or descending depending on `order()`.
 89                If there are multiple generators, the set of outcomes is the
 90                union of the outcomes of the invididual generators. All outcomes
 91                with nonzero count will be seen. Outcomes with zero count
 92                may or may not be seen. If you need to enforce that certain
 93                outcomes are seen even if they have zero count, see
 94                `alignment()`.
 95            *counts: One value (usually an `int`) for each generator output
 96                indicating how many of the current outcome were produced.
 97                All outcomes with nonzero count are guaranteed to be seen.
 98                To guarantee that outcomes are seen even if they have zero
 99                count, override `alignment()`.
100
101        Returns:
102            A hashable object indicating the next state.
103            The special value `icepool.Reroll` can be used to immediately remove
104            the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.
105        """

State transition function.

This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome, and the number that outcome produced by each generator.

evaluate() will always call this using only positional arguments. Furthermore, there is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle an arbitrary number of counts. Thus, you are free to rename any of the parameters in a subclass, or to replace *counts with a fixed set of parameters.

Make sure to handle the base case where state is None.

States must be hashable. At current, they do not have to be orderable. However, this may change in the future, and if they are not totally orderable, you must override final_outcome to create totally orderable final outcomes.

The behavior of returning a Die from next_state is currently undefined.

Arguments:
  • state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the current outcome. If this is the first outcome being considered, state will be None.
  • outcome: The current outcome. next_state will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order; either ascending or descending depending on order(). If there are multiple generators, the set of outcomes is the union of the outcomes of the invididual generators. All outcomes with nonzero count will be seen. Outcomes with zero count may or may not be seen. If you need to enforce that certain outcomes are seen even if they have zero count, see alignment().
  • *counts: One value (usually an int) for each generator output indicating how many of the current outcome were produced. All outcomes with nonzero count are guaranteed to be seen. To guarantee that outcomes are seen even if they have zero count, override alignment().
Returns:

A hashable object indicating the next state. The special value icepool.Reroll can be used to immediately remove the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.

def final_outcome( self, final_state: Hashable, /, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Any: 
107    def final_outcome(self, final_state: Hashable, /,
108                      *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Any:
109        """Optional function to generate a final outcome from a final state.
110
111        Tthere is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle
112        an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of
113        the parameters in a subclass, or to replace `*generators` with a fixed
114        set of parameters.
115
116        By default, the final outcome is equal to the final state.
117        Note that `None` is not a valid outcome for a `Die`,
118        and if there are no outcomes, the final state will be `None`.
119        Subclasses that want to handle this case should explicitly define what
120        happens.
121
122        Args:
123            final_state: A state after all outcomes have been processed.
124            *generators: One or more `OutcomeCountGenerator`s being evaluated.
125                Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and
126                can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named
127                parameters.
128
129        Returns:
130            A final outcome that will be used as part of constructing the result `Die`.
131            As usual for `Die()`, this could itself be a `Die` or `icepool.Reroll`.
132        """
133        return final_state

Optional function to generate a final outcome from a final state.

Tthere is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of the parameters in a subclass, or to replace *generators with a fixed set of parameters.

By default, the final outcome is equal to the final state. Note that None is not a valid outcome for a Die, and if there are no outcomes, the final state will be None. Subclasses that want to handle this case should explicitly define what happens.

Arguments:
  • final_state: A state after all outcomes have been processed.

def order( self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> icepool.Order: 
135    def order(self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Order:
136        """Optional function to determine the order in which `next_state()` will see outcomes.
137

159        """

225    def evaluate(
226        self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator | Mapping[Any, int] |
227        Sequence
228    ) -> 'icepool.Die':
229        """Evaluates generator(s).
230
231        You can call the `OutcomeCountEvaluator` object directly for the same effect,
232        e.g. `sum_evaluator(generator)` is an alias for `sum_evaluator.evaluate(generator)`.
233
234        Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of generators.
235        The union of the outcomes of the generator(s) must be totally orderable.
236
237        Args:
238            *generators: Each element may be one of the following:
239                * A `OutcomeCountGenerator`.
240                * A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
241                * A sequence of arguments to create a `Pool`.
242
243        Returns:
244            A `Die` representing the distribution of the final score.
245        """
246
247        # Convert non-`Pool` arguments to `Pool`.
248        converted_generators = tuple(
249            generator if isinstance(generator, icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator
250                                   ) else icepool.Pool(generator)
251            for generator in generators)
252
253        if not all(generator._is_resolvable()
254                   for generator in converted_generators):
255            return icepool.Die([])
256
257        algorithm, order = self._select_algorithm(*converted_generators)
258
259        # We use a separate class to guarantee all outcomes are visited.
260        alignment = Alignment(self.alignment(*converted_generators))
261
262        dist = algorithm(order, alignment, tuple(converted_generators))
263
264        final_outcomes = []
265        final_weights = []
266        for state, weight in dist.items():
267            outcome = self.final_outcome(state, *converted_generators)
268            if outcome is None:
269                raise TypeError(

271                    "This may have resulted from supplying an empty generator to OutcomeCountEvaluator. "
272                    "If so, refrain from using empty generators, or override OutcomeCountEvaluator.final_outcome() to handle this case."
273                )
274            if outcome is not icepool.Reroll:
275                final_outcomes.append(outcome)
276                final_weights.append(weight)
277
278        return icepool.Die(final_outcomes, final_weights,
279                           **self.final_kwargs(*converted_generators))

Evaluates generator(s).

You can call the OutcomeCountEvaluator object directly for the same effect, e.g. sum_evaluator(generator) is an alias for sum_evaluator.evaluate(generator).

Most evaluators will expect a fixed number of generators. The union of the outcomes of the generator(s) must be totally orderable.

Arguments:
  • *generators: Each element may be one of the following:
    • A OutcomeCountGenerator.
    • A mappable mapping dice to the number of those dice.
    • A sequence of arguments to create a Pool.
Returns:

A Die representing the distribution of the final score.

def sample( self, *generators: Union[icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator, Mapping[Any, int], Sequence]): 
441    def sample(self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator |
442               Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence):
443        """EXPERIMENTAL: Samples one result from the generator(s) and evaluates the result."""
444        # Convert non-`Pool` arguments to `Pool`.
445        converted_generators = tuple(
446            generator if isinstance(generator, icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator
447                                   ) else icepool.Pool(generator)
448            for generator in generators)
449
450        result = self.evaluate(*itertools.chain.from_iterable(
451            generator.sample() for generator in converted_generators))
452
453        if not result.is_empty():
454            return result.outcomes()[0]
455        else:
456            return result

class JointEvaluator(icepool.OutcomeCountEvaluator): 
32class JointEvaluator(OutcomeCountEvaluator):
33    """EXPERIMENTAL: An `OutcomeCountEvaluator` that jointly evaluates sub-evaluators on the same roll(s) of a generator.
34
35    It may be more efficient to write the joint evaluation directly; this is
36    provided as a convenience.
37    """
38
39    def __init__(self, *sub_evaluators: OutcomeCountEvaluator):
40        self._sub_evaluators = sub_evaluators
41
42    def next_state(self, state, outcome, *counts: int) -> tuple[Hashable, ...]:
43        """Runs `next_state` for all subevals.
44
45        The state is a tuple of the substates.
46        """
47        if state is None:
48            return tuple(
49                evaluator.next_state(None, outcome, *counts)
50                for evaluator in self._sub_evaluators)
51        else:
52            return tuple(
53                evaluator.next_state(substate, outcome, *counts)
54                for evaluator, substate in zip(self._sub_evaluators, state))
55
56    def final_outcome(self, final_state,
57                      *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator):
58        """Runs `final_state` for all subevals.
59
60        The final outcome is a tuple of the final suboutcomes.
61        """
62        return tuple(
63            evaluator.final_outcome(final_substate, *generators) for evaluator,
64            final_substate in zip(self._sub_evaluators, final_state))
65
66    def order(self, *generators: icepool.OutcomeCountGenerator) -> Order:
67        """Determines the common order of the subevals.
68
69        Raises:
70            ValueError: If subevals have conflicting orders, i.e. some are
71                ascending and others are descending.
72        """
73        suborders = tuple(
74            evaluator.order(*generators) for evaluator in self._sub_evaluators)
75        ascending = any(x > 0 for x in suborders)
76        descending = any(x < 0 for x in suborders)
77        if ascending and descending:
78            raise ValueError('Sub-evals have conflicting orders.')
79        elif ascending:
80            return Order.Ascending
81        elif descending:
82            return Order.Descending
83        else:
84            return Order.Any

EXPERIMENTAL: An OutcomeCountEvaluator that jointly evaluates sub-evaluators on the same roll(s) of a generator.

It may be more efficient to write the joint evaluation directly; this is provided as a convenience.

 95            self._sub = lambda outcome: outcome

Optional function to generate a final outcome from a final state.

Tthere is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of the parameters in a subclass, or to replace *generators with a fixed set of parameters.

By default, the final outcome is equal to the final state. Note that None is not a valid outcome for a Die, and if there are no outcomes, the final state will be None. Subclasses that want to handle this case should explicitly define what happens.

Arguments:
  • final_state: A state after all outcomes have been processed.
  • *generators: One or more OutcomeCountGenerators being evaluated. Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named parameters.
Returns:

A final outcome that will be used as part of constructing the result Die. As usual for Die(), this could itself be a Die or icepool.Reroll.

def order(self, *_): 
119    def order(self, *_):
120        return Order.Any

Optional function to determine the order in which next_state() will see outcomes.

There is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle an arbitrary number of generators. Thus, you are free to rename any of the parameters in a subclass, or to replace *generators with a fixed set of parameters.

The default is ascending order. This works well with mixed standard dice, and other dice that differ only by right-truncation.

Arguments:
  • *generators: One or more OutcomeCountGenerators being evaluated. Most subclasses will expect a fixed number of generators and can replace this variadic parameter with a fixed number of named parameters.
Returns:
  • Order.Ascending (= 1) if next_state() should always see the outcomes in ascending order.
  • Order.Descending (= -1) if next_state() should always see the outcomes in descending order.
  • Order.Any (= 0) if the result of the evaluation is order-independent.

126class ExpandEvaluator(OutcomeCountEvaluator):
127    """Expands all results of a generator.

129    This is expensive and not recommended unless there are few possibilities.

143        if self._unique:

State transition function.

This should produce a state given the previous state, an outcome, and the number that outcome produced by each generator.

evaluate() will always call this using only positional arguments. Furthermore, there is no expectation that a subclass be able to handle an arbitrary number of counts. Thus, you are free to rename any of the parameters in a subclass, or to replace *counts with a fixed set of parameters.

Make sure to handle the base case where state is None.

States must be hashable. At current, they do not have to be orderable. However, this may change in the future, and if they are not totally orderable, you must override final_outcome to create totally orderable final outcomes.

The behavior of returning a Die from next_state is currently undefined.

Arguments:
  • state: A hashable object indicating the state before rolling the current outcome. If this is the first outcome being considered, state will be None.
  • outcome: The current outcome. next_state will see all rolled outcomes in monotonic order; either ascending or descending depending on order(). If there are multiple generators, the set of outcomes is the union of the outcomes of the invididual generators. All outcomes with nonzero count will be seen. Outcomes with zero count may or may not be seen. If you need to enforce that certain outcomes are seen even if they have zero count, see alignment().
  • *counts: One value (usually an int) for each generator output indicating how many of the current outcome were produced. All outcomes with nonzero count are guaranteed to be seen. To guarantee that outcomes are seen even if they have zero count, override alignment().
Returns:

A hashable object indicating the next state. The special value icepool.Reroll can be used to immediately remove the state from consideration, effectively performing a full reroll.

151        return Order.Any

class Deck(abc.ABC, typing.Mapping[typing.Any, int]): 
 18class Deck(Population):
 19    """Sampling without replacement (within a single evaluation).
 20
 21    Quantities represent duplicates.
 22    """
 23
 24    _data: Counts
 25    _deal: int
 26
 27    def _new_type(self) -> type:
 28        return Deck
 29
 30    def __new__(cls,
 31                outcomes: Mapping[Any, int] | Sequence,
 32                times: Sequence[int] | int = 1) -> 'Deck':
 33        """Constructor for a `Deck`.
 34
 35        Args:
 36            outcomes: The cards of the `Deck`. This can be one of the following:
 37                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
 38                * A sequence of outcomes.
 39
 40                Note that `Die` and `Deck` both count as `Mapping`s.
 41
 42                Each card may be one of the following:
 43                * A `Mapping` from outcomes to quantities.
 44                    The outcomes of the `Mapping` will be "flattened" into the
 45                    result. This option will be taken in preference to treating
 46                    the `Mapping` itself as an outcome even if the `Mapping`
 47                    itself is hashable and totally orderable. This means that
 48                    `Die` and `Deck` will never be outcomes.
 49                * A tuple of outcomes.
 50                    Any tuple elements that are `Mapping`s will expand the
 51                    tuple according to their independent joint distribution.
 52                    For example, `(d6, d6)` will expand to 36 ordered tuples
 53                    with dup 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a
 54                    large number of outcomes.
 55                * `str` or `bytes`, which will be treated as a single outcome.
 56                * Any other sequence. Each element will be weighted equally.
 57                * Anything else will be treated as a single outcome.
 58                    Each outcome must be hashable, and the
 59                    set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion).
 60                    The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case
 61                    the corresponding quantities will be accumulated.
 62            times: Multiplies the number of times each element of `outcomes`
 63                will be put into the `Deck`.
 64                `times` can either be a sequence of the same length as
 65                `outcomes` or a single `int` to apply to all elements of
 66                `outcomes`.
 67        """
 68        if isinstance(outcomes, Deck):
 69            if times == 1:
 70                return outcomes
 71            else:
 72                outcomes = outcomes._data
 73
 74        if icepool.again.contains_again(outcomes):
 75            raise ValueError('Again cannot be used with Decks.')
 76
 77        outcomes, times = icepool.creation_args.itemize(outcomes, times)
 78
 79        if len(outcomes) == 1 and times[0] == 1 and isinstance(
 80                outcomes[0], Deck):
 81            return outcomes[0]
 82
 83        data = icepool.creation_args.expand_args_for_deck(outcomes, times)
 84        return Deck._new_deck(data)
 85
 86    @classmethod
 87    def _new_deck(cls, data: Counts) -> 'Deck':
 88        """Creates a new `Deck` using already-processed arguments.
 89
 90        Args:
 91            data: At this point, this is a Counts.
 92        """
 93        self = super(Population, cls).__new__(cls)
 94        self._data = data
 95        return self
 96
 97    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView:
 98        return self._data.keys()
 99
100    def values(self) -> CountsValuesView:
101        return self._data.values()
102
103    def items(self) -> CountsItemsView:
104        return self._data.items()
105
106    def __getitem__(self, outcome) -> int:
107        return self._data[outcome]
108
109    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator:
110        return iter(self.keys())
111
112    def __len__(self) -> int:
113        return len(self._data)
114
115    size = icepool.Population.denominator
116
117    @cached_property
118    def _popped_min(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
119        return self._new_deck(self._data.remove_min()), self.quantities()[0]
120
121    def _pop_min(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
122        """A `Deck` with the min outcome removed."""
123        return self._popped_min
124
125    @cached_property
126    def _popped_max(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
127        return self._new_deck(self._data.remove_max()), self.quantities()[-1]
128
129    def _pop_max(self) -> tuple['Deck', int]:
130        """A `Deck` with the max outcome removed."""
131        return self._popped_max
132
133    def deal(self, *hand_sizes: int) -> 'icepool.Deal':
134        """Creates a `Deal` object from this deck.
135
136        See `Deal()` for details.
137        """
138        return icepool.Deal(self, *hand_sizes)
139
140    def sub(self, repl: Callable | Mapping, /, star: int = 0) -> 'Deck':
141        """Changes outcomes of the `Deck` to other outcomes.
142
143        You can think of this as `sub`stituting outcomes of this `Deck` for
144        other outcomes.
145
146        Args:
147            repl: One of the following:
148                * A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
149                * A map from old outcomes to new outcomes.
150                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
151                The new outcomes may be `Deck`s, in which case one card is
152                replaced with several. This is not recommended.
153            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes of `self` will be unpacked as
154                `*outcome` before giving it to the `repl` function. `extra_dice`
155                are not unpacked. If `repl` is not a callable, this has no
156                effect.
157        """
158        # Convert to a single-argument function.
159        if callable(repl):
160            if star:
161
162                def transition_function(outcome):
163                    return repl(*outcome)
164            else:
165
166                def transition_function(outcome):
167                    return repl(outcome)
168        else:
169            # repl is a mapping.
170            def transition_function(outcome):
171                if outcome in repl:
172                    return repl[outcome]
173                else:
174                    return outcome
175
176        return Deck(
177            [transition_function(outcome) for outcome in self.outcomes()],
178            times=self.quantities())
179
180    @cached_property
181    def _key_tuple(self) -> tuple:
182        return Deck, tuple(self.items())
183
184    def __eq__(self, other) -> bool:
185        if not isinstance(other, Deck):
186            return False
187        return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple
188
189    @cached_property
190    def _hash(self) -> int:
191        return hash(self._key_tuple)
192
193    def __hash__(self) -> int:
194        return self._hash
195
196    def __repr__(self) -> str:
197        inner = ', '.join(
198            f'{outcome}: {quantity}' for outcome, quantity in self.items())
199        return type(self).__qualname__ + '({' + inner + '})'

Constructor for a Deck.

Arguments:

  • outcomes: The cards of the Deck. This can be one of the following:

    • A Mapping from outcomes to quantities.
    • A sequence of outcomes.

    Note that Die and Deck both count as Mappings.

    Each card may be one of the following:

    • A Mapping from outcomes to quantities. The outcomes of the Mapping will be "flattened" into the result. This option will be taken in preference to treating the Mapping itself as an outcome even if the Mapping itself is hashable and totally orderable. This means that Die and Deck will never be outcomes.
    • A tuple of outcomes. Any tuple elements that are Mappings will expand the tuple according to their independent joint distribution. For example, (d6, d6) will expand to 36 ordered tuples with dup 1 each. Use this carefully since it may create a large number of outcomes.
    • str or bytes, which will be treated as a single outcome.
    • Any other sequence. Each element will be weighted equally.
    • Anything else will be treated as a single outcome. Each outcome must be hashable, and the set of outcomes must be totally orderable (after expansion). The same outcome can appear multiple times, in which case the corresponding quantities will be accumulated.
  • times: Multiplies the number of times each element of outcomes will be put into the Deck. times can either be a sequence of the same length as outcomes or a single int to apply to all elements of outcomes.

def sub( self, repl: Union[Callable, Mapping], /, star: int = 0) -> icepool.Deck: 
140    def sub(self, repl: Callable | Mapping, /, star: int = 0) -> 'Deck':
141        """Changes outcomes of the `Deck` to other outcomes.
142
143        You can think of this as `sub`stituting outcomes of this `Deck` for
144        other outcomes.
145
146        Args:
147            repl: One of the following:
148                * A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
149                * A map from old outcomes to new outcomes.
150                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
151                The new outcomes may be `Deck`s, in which case one card is
152                replaced with several. This is not recommended.
153            star: If set to `True` or 1, outcomes of `self` will be unpacked as
154                `*outcome` before giving it to the `repl` function. `extra_dice`
155                are not unpacked. If `repl` is not a callable, this has no
156                effect.
157        """
158        # Convert to a single-argument function.
159        if callable(repl):
160            if star:
161
162                def transition_function(outcome):
163                    return repl(*outcome)
164            else:
165
166                def transition_function(outcome):
167                    return repl(outcome)
168        else:
169            # repl is a mapping.
170            def transition_function(outcome):
171                if outcome in repl:
172                    return repl[outcome]
173                else:
174                    return outcome
175
176        return Deck(
177            [transition_function(outcome) for outcome in self.outcomes()],
178            times=self.quantities())

Changes outcomes of the Deck to other outcomes.

You can think of this as substituting outcomes of this Deck for other outcomes.

Arguments:
  • repl: One of the following:
    • A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
    • A map from old outcomes to new outcomes. Unmapped old outcomes stay the same. The new outcomes may be Decks, in which case one card is replaced with several. This is not recommended.
  • star: If set to True or 1, outcomes of self will be unpacked as *outcome before giving it to the repl function. extra_dice are not unpacked. If repl is not a callable, this has no effect.
